First, let me start out by saying THE TRAILERS DO NOT DO THIS GAME JUSTICE. I hesitated buying this game at first because the combat didn't look very good and the game didn't look too polished. BOY WAS I WRONG. This has got to be the most polished experience I've played in VR, and the combat was incredibly fun. The swordplay is incredibly polished and I can tell the developer spent a long time perfecting it. It's the most satisfying thing to defeat an enemy in this game. The room scale implementation works well, as you can actively dodge attacks by quickly moving around and lean in for a closer attack on a more exposed area of an enemy.

I can't quite say it'll be worth it for everyone to buy this game for 20 bucks for only a few hours of gameplay, but I sure think it is, although I bought it on sale because I didn't think it was gonna be as good as it is. Those first few hours you get out of it are A BLAST. And then chapter 2 does add a good amount of replay value with it's arena style levels.

All in all, great game. Best VR experience I've had so far. Very immersive and beautiful, and solid controls.

39429571.review:
Definitely an interesting experience to start with, but held back by weak gameplay mechanics, as an experimental game developed by what I believe is a single person, it is good, however, the price tag, as with other VR games, is too steep.


The combat systems in the game certainly have some strong points; enemy armor and shields are reliable and interesting, melee combat is fun and the highly-telegraphed nature of all the moves allow ample time for even a new player to block an attack.

However, these all fall apart once movement gets involved, and while thumbstick-movement has been enabled in this game, a simple solution to all of these attacks is to walk backwards an inch, then walk forward as the enemy is winding down. Enemy arrows and projectiles become nothing but a reason to strafe back and forth as you throw arrows back at these enemies. Bosses desperately try to backpedal from you as you walk into them so that they can actually hit you, allowing the player to hold one joystick forward as they wiggle their wrist, defeating the enemy boss at little to no cost.

Enemy AI is also distressing; the first couple enemies will spawn in close to the player with an animation, but once this stops, enemies begin to show up standing lifelessly in plain view as they wait for the player to approach them; melee becomes a second thought as the ranged options of the game always overpower enemies who cannot or dare not approach, even with their occasional attempts to block and sidestep incoming arrows.

I have multiple other issues with this games' design, such as some assets not really matching the rest of the game or the gold system, but the aforementioned are the primary reasons.

Admittedly, as this is made by a small team, or single person, I couldn't say I expect them to cover all these bases, and I don't know how many of the mechanics in this game are stock unity assets from the store, but some of these systems are worth praise for a solo developer.

However, the size of the development team clearly hasn't affected the size of the hole in my pocket. This game is certainly not worth £15, nor do I think it's worth the £9 on sale; the rose-tinted goggles of VR itself have definitely lowered the bar of quality for games, because this game is certainly not deserving of its' overwhelmingly positive reviews.

39429079.review:
Overall, this is a fun adventure game that kept my interest. I felt invested in the plot and wanted to see more of the world. It is, however, short. I completed it in one evening (3-4 hours) and I am definitely NOT some kind of gaming maestro. You COULD go back and try to get all the achievements (objects collected, etc) but I personally won't - it doesn't have that kind of replay value for me.

In terms of gameplay, I like the style / design, but the movement dynamics could use a lot of work - half the time it didn't detect that I moved (Oculus, 3 sensors here) and any deaths were usually because it was taking me 20 seconds to get the thing to register my teleportation. Still fun, despite that frustration. 7/10, with points deducted for the teleportation problems and how short it is.

39428193.review:
Remember Knightmare?  (if you're not in the UK, and not over 40... probably not...)

This is pretty much it.  74 mins in one session, I have no idea how far I am in, but I just fought may way into a large keep, currently on a quest for a fire wand.  And I'm knackered!

Excellent, yet simple combat?  Oh yes.  Like swords?  Good, you need to swing it quite often.  Parry?  Absolutely perfect.  Ok, the weapon blocking hit box is a little generous... put it down to being a master swordsman.. but hell if it isn't fun to not bother with the shield and just go toe to toe with some undead.

I hope this game is developed way past what there is right now, because quite frankly, I'm not sure I want to stop playing... 

Graphically, it's pretty simple - but then that obviously helps with the performance, which I had no issues at all.  Hand holding?  Hell no, you get some cryptic clues occasionally, but it's definitely up to you to figure stuff out, and it's great to actually have to think to solve the relatively simple, but not always obvious puzzles.

Climbing chains to reach hidden treasure is just another great addition to the game.  

This is VR done right.  Simple, yes.  It's hardly Skyrim - but it doesn't need or pretend to be, it's glorious in it's ease of play.  Could the pick up/drop controls be a little tighter? Maybe.  

All that's missing is a Dungeon Master to recite: Spellcasting.  D I S M I S S.....

39288862.review:
FINALLY got around to finishing this. I have to say, it is one of my favorite VR games now. 

The combat takes some getting used to. It can feel clunky at first, but during the game I grew to really like it. Sure, it's not perfect, but once you know how it works, it actually feels really cool to block or parry enemy's swings and hit him right in the weak spot. Enemies are invulnerable on armor and carry shields they know how to use, so you have to think a little to get hits in. Feels great if you manage to win a 1v2 flawlessly, or defeat some of the stronger enemies.
Ranged weapons are good, but I believe it is MUCH better with a decent play space. Moving furniture, I got to around 2m x 2m which was great. More is probably useless, since the game doesn't actually allow you to move freely, moving away from the center will pause the game. It can be annoying, but it was also helpful to stop me from running into walls. It still allows enough movement to dodge ranged attacks by sidestepping them or getting behind cover. Shooting an enemy while leaning out of cover is a cool thing too.

The world is built beautifully for VR, there's stuff to explore, things to interact with, and the path, while kinda linear, feels like a journey. The only part I disliked is the "maze", because it is very dark and VERY cramped. I'm sure that's what they were going for, because I have to admit, I was just too much of a pussy to play through it. It was scary for me, I had to have my wife next to me watching it to get through. Felt great to get out of it too! And actually using a torch in an rpg with your actual hand to light stuff up feels great too.

It's on the shorter side I guess, with 2.5 hours of play time for me for the normal story mode. There is a hard mode which I have yet to try. But the story was cool and left me wanting for more.

38394635.review:
I'm always a little skeptical of Early Access games, but this one is good...very good.
It completely draws you in, you'll think you're crawling through a dungeon instead of standing in a living room. My friend got ambushed by an archer, and he ducked and took a step back to hide behind a wall; later he was trying to reach something, couldn't quite make so he jumped and smashed the controller into the ceiling, no harm done.
Drawing the bow is so close to real that you feel phantom resistence.
That's how much this game draws you in. And lets talk about options...
Lefyt? Sword in the left hand, shield in the right.
Dual Wielding, check...kill those boxes and barrels in one swipe.
Bow and arrow for a pseudo-stealthy archer, check and unlimited arrows. Angle and draw effect arrow range and arc.
Want to be "the one", put a sword in each hand and Neo out of the way of all incoming attacks.

Hit boxes are on point. A hard, fully extended jab to an armored area will do damage, whereas a light fast jab to the same area will do no damage; but if you hit an unarmored area, you get full damage with just a light hit.

We didn't get far enough to try out magic, so no comment.

One thing...I like how mobs don't aggro out of their area...but if I'm beating on them from a distance...they should come at me.

Hopefully now that the refactor is done, we'll see more content in the coming year. Even if not, at $20 this game is totally worth it.

38393430.review:
Probably my favorite VR game, and the one I most want to get a sequel.

Its like if Zelda were a vr game. It has everything you'd imagine. Skeleton monsters, swords, bow and arrow, sheilds, all with very good controls. Infact the controls are probably the best I've ever seen in VR. Everything from putting an apple in your pouch, to shooting a wizard in the face feels so intuivite and nice. I wish superhot had throwing physics this intuitive. Watch out if you have a low ceiling though.

The axe and the enemy types are my only complaints. The two handed axe feels off, and there are only a few enemies types before the game just shrugs and starts reskinning the same things with more health. But a couple really solidly designed monster types is much better than a thousand badly made ones. So its a fair trade off. Especially for a 20 dollar VR game with amazing visuals and gameplay.

Highly recommend. If I could only show someone on game on VR, I'd pick this one.

38366943.review:
What a frickin riot. Being an old "hack and slash" gamer in his late 50's, I have to tell you that this was a total blast. At first I was wondering (and worried) if I would be able to save my progress, but I soon found that there were save points in areas that made sense. 
The tracking is on point, my arrows hit exactly where I aimed them. Felt great.
The endgame was a trip. Making it throught the challenges had me literally sweating and looking around for whatever was coming next. 
Although not a true RPG in the sense of an open world goliath, the game gave me a great sense of what was coming in VR. The graphics are tight and the item menu's are intuitive and extremely easy to navigate, even during harried battle action. 
The graphics are outstanding. 
If you are new to VR and want an outstanding experience with a sword and bow, there is nothing beter out there.

Presently, I have died a few times cause the weapons I'm holding aren't moving since I have my back to the sensors.  2)  Have a button that extends the reach of an arm. 38170076.review:
Man I love this game. This is like a hybrid of Zelda, Ultima Underworld and D&D. The ability to manipulate your environment is vastly superior in this game to other VR dungeon crawlers that I've tried. The feeling of combat is just right (maybe a little more feedback from the controller when blocking or striking but otherwise great). If I had to nitpick, I'd say I would prefer just tapping the right stick to snapturn as opposed to holding it down and moving it left or right. That makes your thumb really sore after extended play. Also, just a personal preference, but I prefer using a button on the right controller for teleport as in most other games that support teleportation. Those could be easily added as options I would imagine. Maybe a little bit better save management would be nice. Other than that, this game is a masterpiece. It is exactly what I always dreamed a VR dungeon crawler could be. I love the scrolls you find and the way you handled secrets, traps and puzzles. The atmosphere is spot on. Very old school but in a really welcome way. It almost feels like you're playing an early Moldvay-Cook D&D module. (I know...I really dated myself there).

If you ever create a sequel I'd love to see classes to choose from, even more interactivity (maybe NPCs, more formalized quests etc). Cannot wait to try the next chapters. Keep them coming forever! I don't mind paying more to continue playing this gem. You should be proud of yourself. Anyone on the fence about this game, doubtful anyone would be at this point with its amazing history and reviews, buy it now. Do not wait. Btw, if it matters I am playing it on the Rift and I have absolutely no problems (minus my preferences as stated earlier).

38045921.review:
[code][b]Dec 3      Overall Score 10/10      Price $19.99[/b][/code]

If you're reading this, then you likely haven't played this game yet for some reason.  You need to remedy that immediately.  Like, stop reading reviews and go buy this thing.

Vanishing Realms is [i]the[/i] game that's mentioned every time a dungeon crawler or RPG in VR is mentioned.  And for good reason.  The game is highly polished and incredibly fun.  if you're worried about the pricetag, don't be.  It's worth every penny.  This is the game that all the others in this genre are trying to imitate.

[table]
  [tr]
    [td]Value[/td]
    [td]7/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]Originality[/td]
    [td]10/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]Controls[/td]
    [td]10/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]Graphics[/td]
    [td]8/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]Sound[/td]
    [td]7/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]Fun[/td]
    [td]10/10[/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td][b]Overall[/b][/td]
    [td]10/10[/td]
  [/tr]
[/table]

[b][u]Value - 7[/u][/b] - The only reason I didn't give it a higher score, is that I realize the price is kind of high.  Also, even though the game is tons of fun, it is a tad short (shouldn't take more than a couple of hours for a first playthrough, and they can be done in maybe 45 minutes after that).  Replayability is a bit on the low side as well.

[b][u]Originality - 10[/u][/b] - As I said before, this has become the standard for this adventure genre in VR.  There's some similar types of games in non-VR (perhaps Skyrim... but more linear.. a good example isn't coming to mind).  

[b][u]Controls - 10[/u][/b] - Pretty much every imaginable control scheme has been implemented at this point.  You've got teleportation, gliding, umm... some others (a combo of teleportation and glide is all I use).  Sword fighting (and archery) are both well done.  Movement is smooth, and hits on the enemies are accurate.

One thing in particular I thought was fun, was if you're at a place where a melee enemy can't reach you and are shooting it with arrows, after a hit or two they begin side-stepping your arrows.  It's still possible to hit them, but it makes for a difficult tactic.

Also, after a bit you get a mining pick and these little ore nodes become another source of income.  Mining them is quite fun and feels very Minecraft-y... but there's not so many nodes that it becomes tedious.

[b][u]Graphics - 8[/u][/b] - The graphics are a bit cartoony, but it works.  Generally, I prefer a cartoony look to badly-done realism.  Gives a nice buffer where you can excuse things that aren't quite right.  Enemy models aren't overly stiff, and move well; although combat feels a little basic.  The terrain layout and textures are good as well.

[b][u]Sound - 7[/u][/b] - Sound is ok.  Sounds effects are what they need to be.  Enemies yell at you a little and make some noise.  I can't recall if there's background music or not (which I suppose isn't a good sign).  I don't recall if there's ambiance sound effects either.

[b][u]Fun - 10[/u][/b] - The game is pretty good at making you feel like a badass with a sword and shield.  Enemies are just tough enough (unless you're a Gorn expert... in which case combat won't be too difficult).  There's a good mix of melee skeletons, archers, spell casters, and giants to fight.  You end up armed with a sword and shield, bow, fireball wand, and 2-handed axe (which is a bit difficult to get the hang of... and again having played Gorn would be helpful here).  

[b][u]Overall - 10[/u][/b] - You spend just enough time exploring and poking around in boxes and burning piles of leaves/straw on the floor looking for treasure with interspersed combat to keep things from getting to tedious or boring.  Level layout is good.  Just complex enough in places to make you feel a little lost, without being too difficult to actually find your way through.  

Do yourself a favor and make this game happen.

37971980.review:
Perhaps one of the best Vive games out there. Feels polished and well-concieved.

Basically it's more or less linear dungeon crawler / simplish RPG, sure, but it does everything soo well compared to other VR games. The inventory system is excellent and still simple to use, the combat feels right and makes you move in room space a bit swinging sword or taking covers from enemy arrows, the level design allows for some movements to grab items out of reach/behind stone pillar etc. Movement can be both teleportation (feels ok in here) and touchpad. Extra point for very nice chaperon implementation where moving too fast or swinging too fast outside of boundaries pauses the game and forces player to re-center.

Graphics are a bit on cartoonish side style wise (it's usually BIG no-no for some like me) but in VR it works creating nice and immersive for most parts fairytale environment.

There are some little puzzles here but this title begs for more physics based ones IMO.

Haven't completed, people say it's short like most VR games tend to be -but apparently it's the base Author will build on additional content.

Thumbs up!

It's a must have for a Vive owner, go get it!

37929428.review:
Wow! What a wonderful game. Although the first two chapters can be finished in a couple of hours, every damn minute of this wonderful (Zelda-like) action oriented RPG is just fantastic entertainment. I had so much fun shooting arrows at flying wizards, chopping my sword at bulky skeletons and blocking crossbow bolts of undead archers with my trusty shield. 

Vanishing Realms is a full room experience. You need that extra space to fight, dodge, parry and slash at anything that comes your way. You can duck behind cover, crawl under perilous blade traps on hands and knees and hoist yourself up on ropes and chains. There is tons of hidden treasure to collect (although it's very easy to max out on the gear you can purchase), some light puzzles to solve and a big dungeon te explore. Stalking through the labyrinthine tunnels, my shield raised for anything that might jump out of the shadows while I was keeping an eye out for traps, was just an overal great experience and one of my best moments I've had in VR so far. 

And while it is not perfect (I'd like to see more RPG influences, a less linear setting, maybe some NPC interaction and even more different locations) Vanishing Realms is a complete and polished VR experience. I never ran into any glitches or errors. Above all else, Vanishing Realm really shows the wild potential of VR. I can't wait to sink my little runesword and teeth in the next chapters when they arrive!

35603116.review:
I've played much worse for more money, this game is definitely worth buying. Control wise, it's very smooth and fluid, and barring the times the controllers got lost (due to myself being in the way of the sensors), the mechanics and swordplay feel really well done. The tone of the game is well established, and although not quite to my personal taste, still well done.

My only major issue is that there's no way to turn around without physically turning your body, which caused the disconnection of the controllers. If our HMDs were wireless, this wouldn't be an issue, but due to the current limitations of being tethered to our computers, it's practically imparitive that we are able to use the controller to turn (via a joystic on the touch controllers, or on of the vive's trackpads). 

Something else I'd like to see is smooth locomotion as an option. I should be able to move out of the way of the enemy's attacks without having to teleport. I know teleportation is a major gameplay neccessity for those gamers who get motion sickness, but for those of us who don't, smooth locomotion give a much more immersive experience. 

There are other tweaks and improvements that could be made, for example the UI seems a little odd in my opinion, having to look down while in a fight to check your health. A suggestion i could make would be to layer a health/mana bar in the top left corner of the player's view so they could look at it when they need to, without losing focus on the enemy. This was done successfully with your score in RoboRecall, where you would look at the bottom corner to check your points, without actually moving your head. 

Although I definitely have suggestions, and there's only one major issue I can see, this game is definitely worth it's salt and the creators should be proud. I'll be keeping an eye on this title, it'll be good to see where swordfighting in VR goes.

35413753.review:
Vanishing Realms - 4 out of 5 stars
Mood and atmosphere were great from the get go. localized torchlight was such a nice touch and the lighting of scenes throughout always impressed me, although dark areas could have been darker. Even without the torch there was only one place i struggled to see clearly. sounds and music added to the dungeon feel. Kudos to the designers.

Game play was very enjoyable with accurate aiming and pinpoint swordplay. you are not going to wildly swing your weapon and expect results. The peril level is fairly low with very few "startling moments" an no "horror" , making this adventure excellent for children. As an adult and veteran gamer I may have asked for more but that is not a criticism. 

There were some times that melee  felt a little lackluster. Here's why.....
Enemies were for the most part activated by proximity not line of sight. you could often stand quite close and just stare at them, so they lacked a "threatening" attitude. It was also easy to stay out of the areas of multiple enemies and engage them one at at time, and too easy to run away. Maybe slow the teleport dot even more than it already moves ( a good feature that is a clever way simulate player run speed)

Lastly, while there were elements of puzzle play most were easy (very easy) and the bosses posed only moderate challenge. I never ran out of health and had ample food to regenerate. There were lots of nooks to look into but few things to collect and (so far) not very many upgrades to shoot for. there wasn't ever i time that an object was out of reach and as far as i can tell  few reasons to revisit past areas. But this was my first go at it  and that was on default settings....and i did not get all achievements. 6 hrs total play time for about $25 is good value and i will play again for some things i am sure i missed.

Vanishing Realms is super fun for everyone. Hoping to see more and I will definitely buy new chapters

35401108.review:
Ok recently got a Rift and have spent a great deal on a multitude of games. I read some Steam reviews on this and they seemed very sure that this was a must try. Have to say that they were spot on.

It IS what VR promised. Hand down.There's a simple joy associated with every action. The bow and arrow, to my absolute delight, seems to be the same mechanic as The Lab. You know the feeling. Precise and fun. You really feel the feedback tension as you pull the arrow back. 

I almost never post reviews (apologies). But this seems to warrant the extra effort on my part.

My only mild gripe would be the click to run and click to turn issue. But its my no means a game breaker. I quickly adapted and proceeded to grin from ear to ear with every moment.

35356326.review:
The first time I played this game after purchasing it, I didn't get very far into it because I didn't have time. 

I finally came back to work my way through it, and it's really quite something!

Pros:
+Visceral combat -- Strategy and shieldwork actually mean something 1v1
+Good archery
+Gorgeous Art Style and Graphics
+Great environments
+Moderate workout
+Eat 30 cheese wedges
+Link vs. vases syndrome

Cons:
-Palsy "magic" late game
-Lots of gold hoarding without much incentive to keep buying new weapons
-VR Beginner difficulty

Long story short, this is a really good VR RPG that can hold it's own weight, given enough time and care during development to carry through the flegling story it's working up to. I was genuinely disappointed when the game ended so abruptly, but it left me wanting more.

35166667.review:
This game delivers the promise of VR.  For a mere $13.99 (current sale price) you get a game that pushed the boundaries of what one could expect in a VR title.  This is a complete VR experience.  Don't let the negative reviews or the status of EA or lack of constant updates stop you from getting this game.  This is a MUST buy VR title.  If you own a Vive, Oculus, whatever, you owe it to yourself to experience this game.

A lot of the negative reviews mention locomotion.  Well, you're not teleporting anymore unless you want to.  You can mostly move freely using your touch controller's joystick.  It's not perfect, you have to click down to go faster or to turn. But it's done very well. 

A lot of the other negative reviews mention lack of updates.  Well, this game is pretty much a finished product.  I have 1.7 hours on Steam currently and I still have not finished the game.  And there's a whole area I haven't explored.  Keep in mind that the normal price is $19.99.  This is a lot of content for the price.  And it's not just average content or above average content, this is AMAZING content for the price.  I played 1.7 hours straight because I was having so much fun.  I plan to get right back into the game later today.  That's because I loved the game world.  I have not experienced any bugs on the Oculus Rift w/ Touch.

The dungeons are so well designed and intuitive.  The puzzles are logical (no having to search for a  key that's hidden in some vase under a cabinet type crap).  The riddles are creative (yes, riddles).  You have different tools at your disposal, including food, pickaxe, torch, sword, shield, bow & arrow, or wand.  Also, climbing up the ropes or chains is just so much fun to get that extra bit of loot or spoiler alert [spoiler] burning curtains to get the items hidden beneath or breaking barrels with your sword to get more coins [/spoiler]

Admittedly, the weakest part of the game is probably the melee combat.  I didn't find it very challenging.  But I did enjoy using the bow and arrow.  And nothing is more satisfying that beating down that skeleton archer with a sword after he's been trying to pick you off.  

Rating 9/10 just a better story and improved melee combat and this game could have been legendary

35145790.review: 整体来说效果相当好，对战玩法很多，刀枪剑斧弓箭都很真实，整体模型做的也相当不错；美中不足的就是故事情节太短，很简单就通关了；希望在后期增加更多的关卡以及更多的游戏模式，如果增加联机，那这个游戏不可限量。

35143804.review:
This game reminds me of DnD advantures we used to play through with my uni friends. A bit simple and a bit naive but captivating nonetheless. Gameplay is based around dungeon crawling with some combat and an occasional puzzle thrown in for good measure. Movement is a combination of roomscale and artificial locomotion with a choice of teleportation and recently added free movement. I particularly enjoy the latter as it is implemented in a way that feels rather natural and is not VR sickness inducing in any way; there are even some advanced anti-sickness options for those who are succeptible. 

All in all it's not a very long game in it's current state, main adventure(chapter 1) is about 4 hours but it was very enjoyable to play and certainly worth the money. Especially so given further expansions are expected with new adventure chapter.

On the technical side, game was running ok on my initial oculus+touch setup but certainly became more comfortable with 3 sensors as there were some issues with dead tracking zones when facing certain directions. Latest patch added optional stick turning so having full 360 tracking is not as importalt now but still preferrable for a more immersive and smooth experience.

35134931.review: I won't play this in it's current state. Overall it's a great game, but although the recent partial addition of free movement has improved things in one area, having to click the thumbstick button to turn incrementally with Touch controllers is a really bad idea.  It makes things fiddly, imprecise and awkward and causes needless wear and tear on the switches, not to mention breaking the immersion. What's wrong with just being able to rotate freely by moving the stick left and right? It works perfectly for other games. Please, just give us free movement - no increments -no buttons. We can handle it, I promise.

34015831.review:
Hace dos días que compré las Oculus Rift y este ha sido uno de los primeros juegos que he jugado después de ver que el 100% de los usuarios lo recomendaba. Dudé un poco por dos cosas. Primero, el juego está en early access. Y segundo, solo da soporte a HTC Vive. Pero os puedo decir que el juego es perfectamente jugable. No he encontrado aún nigún motivo para el estado de early access, excepto un pequeñísimo parpadeo al teletransportarse. Segundo, el juego es completamente compatible con Oculus rift + oculus touch (con la configuracion experimental de 360 grados con dos sensores). Simplemente verás en tus manos los mandos de Vive al principio, aunque rápidamente serán una bola de luz con la que puedes hacer todo lo que haces con los mandos de htc vive. Así que si tienes oculus no tendrás problemas para jugar. 

Adicionalmente es recomendable un area de juego de al menos 2x2m pero no es obligatoria. Tienes un teletransportador que te permite jugar en un area un poco menor. 

El juego está en inglés sin subtítulos. Para mi no es un gran problema, aunque he visto que los acertijos te dan las pistas en un inglés con rimas que puede ser un poco dificil de entender para algunas personas. Aún así no hay mucho texto en el juego, así que no es que te vayas a pasar todo el día mirando el diccionario. 

En lo referente al juego en sí es bastante inmersivo, Me sorprendió mucho verme a mi mismo esquivando flechas, poniéndome en guardia frente a un enemigo. Intentando cubrirme con mi escudo... Esto es lo que se espera de un rpg para realidad virtual. Y sin duda, si alguna vez has deseado estar dentro de tu RPG favorito, esta es una buena ocasión para conseguirlo.  

Muy recomendable sin ninguna duda. Espero que saquen más juegos así, y que mejoren este aún más hasta que deje de ser un early access.

34000578.review: This  game is by far my favorite VR game I have in my collection. I felt very immersed and rather surprised at the depth the enemies had when fighting. I had to learn the move sets of each enemy and know how to properly defend and attack. Looking for openings was the most fun because the enemies even adapted to my fighting style. They would cover and dodge almost as well as the player can. The layout of the dungeons were rather fun to explore. I often found myself wondering if I was going to stumble into a place I wasnt yet prepared for. The map design does a rather good job of encouraging exploration and discovering secrets. Finding all the hidden treasures was my favorite activity because hiding spots become so much harder when you actually have to duck behind things and look above into the rafters. I was throwing rocks before I bought a bow to knock items off of ledges. The things in this game are rather simple in comparison to a AAA RPG but experiencing them makes all the difference. These simple activities become very fun. Seeing a video does not do this game justice, it must be experienced in VR. The art style is also well done in my opinion and is pretty to look at while not making the enemies completely horrifying. While I thouroughly enjoyed this game and it is my favorite. I did feel it was lacking. I just want more, more to explore, more secrets to find, more to discover, more enemyu types, more locomotion options, other NPCs to interact with and buy from. It has a decent weapon selection and the inventory and player information system is by far the most natural and intuitive than any other game I have played. I just want more because it is so good. However considering, as far as I am aware, that this game is made by as single developer I am quite impressed with the game in its current state. I highly recomend getting it so that the developer can do more! It is fully playable in its current state and is a blast. This game is just a taste of the incredible future that VR has to offer. 9/10

33971726.review: This is easily one of my top fav games in VR right now. It's a fun cartoony dungeon exploration game. You roam around exploring the castle and fighting off enemies while avoiding traps and gaining new weapons. You could say it's similar to Zelda, but it is unfortunatly lacking in length. I think the first time I played through it took me around 3 or so hours. Fighting the skeleton knight for the first time was a great experience. If you've never played VR, you suddenly realize there's a seven-foot tall "real" monster in front of you, and you have no idea how to effectively use a sword and shield. In regular games, your character is pre-animated to swing a sword like a badass, and here I am flailing for my life and running into my bedroom walls out of fear. You'd be doing yourself a disservice to miss out on it. I just wish there was more.

33881567.review:
I don't usually write game reviews, but this game really deserve one.
For me, Vanishing Realm shows what VR games should be. It is really immersive with its own style of graphics that makes you spend quite some time looking around you. The interaction with the environment is easy and I especially like the way the teleportation movement was implemented here. Most importantly, the fights were very enjoyable and I had to brace myself quite often to rush into the melee or duck behind a crate and shoot the buggers with my bow.

Now sure the game is still short (especially chapter 2) and it is true that additional content don’t comes out very often. But I still highly recommend this experience and I hope the dev will continue his works on what could be one of the best VR games out there.

33168970.review:
Just ended my first 2 hours of this, my second VR game, and the experience was so incredible that I have to wonder if I can ever be impressed with a non-vr game again. The feeling of immersion, of presence, and danger were a completely new experience. I didn't feel this playing Star Trek Bridge Crew, either, so not all VR games have the magic. You block with a shield and wield a sword, and it feels natural, like your own limbs. I think about all the big-name games defining the cornerstones of gaming through the decades, and they now seem like jokes compared to this.

I just read pcgamer's recommendations on the steam summer sale, and passed up 3 non-vr games I would have gotten just last week. All I want is VR adventure, after playing this.

Edit: Came back after hundreds of hours of dozens of other VR games to try the locomotion update to this game. Made it even better. Immersion still incredible in this game. Still one of the best. After this and Dead Effect 2 VR, I'm done with flat gaming.

32495552.review:
Simply put, this game is what sold me on VR.

Like most, I was extremely skeptical about the very young, very "gimmicky" HTC Vive.

Until my cousin slapped a Vive over my eyes, and put me inside Vanishing Realms - 

- where I was immediately transported to an enormous dungeon of old, wielding but a simple torch as I walked through the first doorway, only to be greeted by a dark, looming evil voice that seemingly came from the walls themselves.

Here, you will explore ancient dungeons, collect coins to buy weapons and items that will decide whether or not you live or die, actually physically crawl through trap rooms just to get to the next hallway, fight skeletons that are bigger than you ever could've imagined, and this is all just in the first 20 minutes of gameplay. 

Here, you will truly get lost in an unreal atmospheric dungeon crawling experience. You will never forget it as long as you live, I guarantee that. There is simply nothing like this game. It's absolutely amazing. It's an essential VR experience for everyone who has VR, and everyone who is skeptical or even just trying VR for the first time. Do not wait. Buy this immediately. 

20/10

31200615.review:
Vanishing Realms "Rite of Steel" gehört derzeit zu den größeren VR Spielen und hat mir insgesamt drei Stunden Spiel, Spaß und Spannung gebracht. Ich kann es klar empfehlen.

Als Glücksritter zieht es Euch auf eine Insel. Unter der Annahme man sei hier allein, erkundet ihr alte Gemäuer, dreckige Gassen aber auch wunderschöne Orte (die ich aus Spoiler gründen nicht genauer beschreiben möchte)
Zunächst mit einer Fackel bewaffnet wird schnell klar, dass man doch nicht ganz so allein ist und sich schnell Waffen (Schwert, Schild, Axt, Bogen etc) organisiert. Ihr kämpft teilweise "Mann gegen Mann" gegen diverse Feinde, müsst Angriffe blocken oder in Deckung gehen, um Pfeilen auszuweichen. Sollte man alle Prüfungen meistern, so wartet am Ende der langersehnte Schatz.

Die Grafik ist angemessen und meines erachtenes ziemlich beeindruckend und hält einige wunderschöne aber düstere Orte und Gegner bereit. Ab und zu hatte ich Probleme mit meinem Spielradius sodass, dass Spiel sofort in die Pause ging, wenn man übertrat. Diese Funktion scheint sinnvoll zu sein, hat mich aber jedesmal aus dem Spiel geholt, bis ich herausgefunden habe, dass man das auch abschalten kann.

Alles in allem ein echt geniales Spiel und ein Pflichtspiel für VR Brillen. Es bisher eines besten Spiele, die ich mit meiner Vive gespielt habe.

31009287.review:
Oh my god. This game is awesome! I can't believe I put off acquiring it for so long! And I can't believe I still think it's awesome now, when it came out way back when Vive was brand new and the bar for content was so low.

This is really excellent. I just spent 90 minutes in it for what was supposed to be a quick look around and just...couldn't leave.

Ok. Criticism. The swordplay feels a bit arcade-like. And it's got the same problem that sword fighting games always have in VR. And I think I have some advice, that I've been handing out to every developer I've found who's working on this kind of thing.

Change your swordfighting mechanic so that it's like when you draw the sword you go into an altered state.

Obviously, this means slow motion. Which is how we all instinctively did sword fighting when we were kids. Because you aren't going to have serious swordplay at real sword-swinging speeds and be able to actually intercept stabs and slashes in a realistic way. Not at speed. Which leaves us with this really imprecise version of swordfighting that's been dumbed down. But that takes the joy out of the swordfight itself! I mean, it's still cool because you're in a mystic cave and you're fighting a skeleton and so on, but the swordfighting part gets old fast because of everything I just described.

So slow it down. Make the swordfight work on a flexible timescale very much like the basic mechanic in SuperHot. When you pick up your sword, everything should slow down to timescale slaved to how fast you move. And if you try to stab your sword through their shield or armor or a wall (i.e., you don't stop swinging when it hits a barrier and you see sparks fly and the controller buzzes in your hand or whatever), you drop your sword and have to duck down and scoop it up (which isn't life threatening in slow-motion...but it's a setback and you probably won't do it too many times in a row).

Then you can make the hitpoints go way, way up in both directions - a hard slash across the belly should be fatal (for the player or the NPC's). Smooth out and polish the animations a bit so they pass muster in slow motion. That especially goes for the animations when you kill them. Maybe work in some halfway-there maiming scripting - if you cut off an arm or leg, they're pretty much done for, but not before they make one or two last clumsy attempts to kill you with their remaining limbs. Do that, and players will actually get really excited about any opportunity for melee combat.

A proper VR full-body experience. Sword-fighting, shields, archery, duck/dodge. Fantastic quality, one of those games I use to introduce newcomers to the fold - always a dropped jaw. Once they're confident, I show them Robo Recall; Vanishing Realms is on that level. 

Like most current VR titles, very short. I played once-through in 1h. Speed-ran the second pass in 10-20m. I like the game enough I just dilly-dally in the world, though I've exhausted it. I hope they release more content soon!

31008335.review:
I was skeptical about getting a game that only has 2 levels and having seen most people beat it in 4 hours.
I've only played an hour so far, and I feel I've already gotten my money worth out of this experience.  I have over 20 games, and a lot of the popular titles.  This is by far my favourite VR experience so far.

A floating inventory system is a great idea.

A fully interactive 3D environment with destructable and tossable tiems, is very well done, and hides treasure in all sorts of places forcing you to look into barrels, under tables, and smash all the things.

The first sword-and-shield melee combat system I've seen that works, and the AI fights in real-time.  Noticed very little errors, tracks, blocks, and hits really well.  

Great game, well worth.  Looking forward to playing more, finishing it, and playing it all over again lol.

30988821.review:
This is a gorgeous game and the exploration is super fun and engaging. The puzzles are pretty fun too.

What kept me from really engjoying it was the combat. It felt very clunky and repetetive. Disabling all hit detection on your weapon after landing a hit doesn't feel like a very good way of handling whatever issues it is trying to prevent (I am guessing kills from just holding your sword inside an enemy). It forces a repetitive "strike, parry, strike, parry" experience that is not very engaging and feels like it is forcing me to play the way the game wants to. Most of the damage I took was from striking and then brining my sword back around for a parry but the blade wasn't turned back on and the enemy just hit me anyway.

I know we are still in the early stages of these kinds of games but it is important to know what works and what doesn't. In my opinion, it does not in this case.

30968776.review:
[h1] A Promising VR Action Adventure RPG[/h1]

This took me much longer to get through than I thought it would, and that's a pleasant surprise. Vanishing Realms is very easy to lose yourself in, and I mean that in a good way. There are some sprawling areas of the world here, though it sometimes feels sparsely populated. You have your melee guys, your ranged folks, your magic fellows, your mini boss types, but they're the only inhabitants of this world. I would have liked to see some wildlife, even if it wasn't interactable (like a scripted scene where something runs out ahead of you) just to give you a sense that there was a living, breathing world here. Maybe there isn't though, and that's the point of the game!

[spoiler] After you complete the first part of the game (the main boss fight), the second part feels... quick, rushed together and more like a wave game than anything else. [/spoiler]

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
     [*]Multiple weapons
     [*]Decent Length
     [*]Combat [i]feels good[/i] when taking it seriously.
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
     [*]Easily exploited combat
     [*]Small variety of enemy types
[/list]

30949113.review:
The first chapter of this game is probably my favorite VR experience so far. It took me about 2.5 hours to complete, and that was with some backtracking for secrets and such. The second chapter is much shorter and while fun, was a bit unsatisfying in the end. Some points of concern I want to mention:

1. You have to buy every equippable with money, with maybe one or two exceptions. Working through a puzzle or fighting through a lot of enemies and getting to the next item but not having enough money to buy it is a pretty bad feeling.

2. The first sword you can buy at the cheapest is fine, I used it all the way through the first chapter. If you want a different one you have to go all the way back and get another, which is long and tedious. They should be spaced out through the level to let you upgrade. Dual-wielding feels pretty awesome and works well too.

3. Don't buy the axe... Just don't. Save your gold. Super unsatisfying damage with some wonky controls. The top tier sword costs less and does more damage. Winding up and swinging it only to have it do no damage off a shield or helmet needs to be fixed. Armor penetration anyone?

Невероятно кругая РПГ-шка для Vive. На данный момент является одним из лучших доступных VR проектов.
Затягивает с первых секунд игры. Полное погружение за счет возможности взаимодействия со всем окружением. Завезли и линейный сюжет, и побочки в стиле фарма голды, поисков тайников, получения ачивок и просто исследования огромного открытого мира. Приятно реализованный инвентарь для всевозможных полезностей.
Радует, что голда собирается не просто так, а для получения более мощного лута - фактически все, что ты находишь, так или иначе станет полезным. Очень интересная механика боя, умные, но не слишком суровые мобы, способные блокировать твои атаки, уклоняться от стрел, прятаться за укрытиями. К счастью, монстра не ломится на тебя скопом и не гоняет по всем локациям, следовательно игра остается проходимой: всю живность надо завалить собственными руками. 
Невероятная атмосфера мистического подземелья чередуется с живописными открытыми пространствами. Перемещение телепортацией - абсолютный плюс для игры: тебе и так приходится крутиться на 360 градусов, при этом игра не укачивает. 
Реиграбельно. Маст хэв для всех, у кого есть вайв и хотя бы пару квадратных метров свободного пространства.

12/10

30758794.review:
Dieses Spiel ist eines der besten VR-Titel für die HTC-Vive, welches ich bislang gespielt habe.

Hier meine positiven und negativen Punkte des Spiels. Unten dran hänge ich dann auch noch einige weitere Ideen, welche ich hätte.

Positiv:
+ Grafik im Comicstil. Man taucht schon in der ersten Sekunde vollkommen ein in diese Welt.
+ Gameplay. Die Waffen funktionieren unglaublich gut und die Schläge sind sehr Präzise. Man hat das Gefühl, man würde       tatsächlich ein Schwert führen oder mit dem Bogen zielen
+ Shops. Es gibt mehrere kleine "Shops" in denen man verschiedene Waffen kaufen kann.
+ Waffenarsenal. Die vielfalt an Waffen ist unglaublich gut. Es gibt 3 verschiedene Schweter, einen Hammer, 2 Bögen, einen Zauberstab (Der Mana benötigt) eine 2-Hand Axt und natürlich einen Schild
+ Atmosphäre. Die Atmosphäre ist düster gehalten und stimmt zum Setting.
+ Mining. Man bekommt im Verlauf des Spiels eine Spitzhacke, mit der man Erze abbauen kann. (Die Erze werden entweder zu Gold oder zu Mana)
+ Das 1. Kapitel. Das erste Kapitel ist unglaublich Detailverliebt, man findet überall interessante Dinge und kommt häufig aus dem Staunen nicht raus. (meine Spielzeit betrug für das 1. Kapitel knapp 3,5 Std. was aber auch daran lag, dass ich mir Zeit für das Spiel genommen habe und nicht durchgerusht bin)
+ Teleportieren. Ich hatte nicht ein einziges Mal einen Anflug von Motionsickness.
+ Die Gegner. Es ist ein unbeschreibliches Gefühl vor den Gegner zu stehen. Besonders die Minibosse, welche gut 2,5 - 3m groß sind, sind beeindruckend!
+ Die Kämpfe. Wenn man mit dem Schwert nicht gerade hin- und herwedelt als sei es ein Staubfänger sind die Kämpfe wahnsinnig gut. Spielt man das Spiel mit Blocken/Parieren - Angreifen, dann fordert einen jeder Kampf aufs neue. Ich habe immer darauf geachtet, was der Gegner als nächstes plant, den Angriff bestmöglichst mit dem Schild geblockt oder dem Schwert/Hammer pariert und dann zugeschlagen. Unglaubliches Gefühl!

Negativ:
- Das 2. Kapitel. Nach dem unglaublich guten Start des 1. Kapitels ist das 2. dann wirklich eine große Enttäuschung. Meine Spielzeit betrug gute 30 Minuten, dann war es schon vorbei. Es ist leider nur eine Arena mit allen bekannten Gegnern, welche Wellenartig mit einem im Ring stehen.
- Die 2-Hand-Axt. Das Kämpfen mit dieser Waffe ist eine einzige Tortur. Ich verstehe die Idee dahinter, aber es funktioniert leider so gar nicht :( Schade.
- Nach einem Neustart des Spiels "spawnen" alle Erze und Äpfel etc. wieder in der Welt. Das macht einige Erfolge etwas unsinnig.


Meine Ideen für Chapter 3 oder Upgrades von Chapter 1&2
○ Crafting. Man bekommt schon im Spielverlauf eine Spitzhacke in die Hand gedrückt, wieso also nicht auch verschiedene Erze abbauen können und vielleicht an einer Schmiede (Welche irgendwo eingebaut werden könnte) sich seine eigenen Waffen bauen?
○ Interaktion mit den Feuerschalen. Häufig findet man Feuerschalen in einem Raum, das Entzünden bewirkt leider gar nichts. Die Schalen könnte man auch dafür benutzen um Gänge freizuschalten oder Türen zu öffnen, statt immer einen Schlüssel oder Hebel zu suchen
○ NPC's in Shops. Was mir sehr gut gefallen würde wären NPC's mit denen man interagieren muss um Gegenstände zu erwerben.

30461747.review: Neat game. I really enjoyed this dungeon romp. I found myself looking under leaves and other things quite often to find the secret items. 30454092.review:
I bought this game on sale thinking it was going to be some 20-30 minute rinky dinky polished VR turd experience. Nope, instead it was the exact opposite. I'm being completely honest here, this game is literally one of the best VR games I've touched on the Vive, all bullsh*t aside. The only other game I've played that actually felt like a FULL game and not a tech demo experience was Lucky's Tale on the Oculus Rift. 

Vanishing Realms took me almost 6 hours to beat, and while that may sound small, that's actually pretty long for a VR title. Honestly I became so immersed in the game that it felt a little bit longer than it actually is due to the sense of presence. In this game you actually FEEL like you're in another world due to the sense of presence, which is most VR titles I think, but this game actually makes you feel like you're a warrior on a quest in a virtual world, it feels legit. The graphics are a bit cartoony but honestly who gives a sh*t? Not this guy.

You fight skeleton warriors, mages, bosses, etc. You can mine ore, use a magic wand, use 3 different types of swords, an axe, hammer, 2 different bows. There's traps to avoid, chalices to collect, not really any puzzles (personally I hate puzzles). The game seems super easy at first, but it starts to get quite challenging. It's not too difficult, but difficult enough that you can't just stand there like a statue swinging your vive controller like an idiot, it requires a bit of tactic and you actually feel like you're fighting a real battle. The enemy AI isn't that great and seems a bit cheap-ish, but I think fighting in this game feels really nice regardless. I used mostly sword, shield, and a bow. The enemies try to swing at you in different ways with their weapons if you fight up close, you can block the incoming attacks with your sword or shield and it feels like you're actually blocking everything, it's very responsive. The game will make you move around a bit (if you have space), and potentially make you work up a sweat lol

I applaud the devs for this, you guys did a really good job. The game isn't super amazing, but it's still a really well made VR title that deserves some attention I think. This is probably the closest thing you're gonna get to an "Elder Scrolls", "Legend of Zelda" kind of experience on VR at the moment, and for 20 bucks it's not bad. I'd say wait for a sale though and grab it if you own a Vive, you won't regret it I promise. It's definitely worth the money out of all the VR turds I've seen on Steam.

30437990.review: Another one of my first VR game. Excellent game!

30437144.review:
This is one of those Vive games that could (and in my mind probably deserves to be) priced higher. There's a lot of fun here, most of it in the world creation and the small areas that flow together well to give you a sense of adventure. The only thing I would like to try is a different, slower locomotion option as the teleporting can allow you to zoom through areas.

The combat is challenging (if not a slight bit wonky) but the weapons are all fun to use. The enemy designs are all really cool too. Threatening in a cartooish way that doesn't come off as silly.

What this game nails though is the overall mood and feel of each area. The spooky castles, the swamps, grand halls filled with fire mages. Each new fight is a new challenge and the backdrops can really add to the tension in some areas.

I've played through the campaign twice now (and will be going through again on Hard Mode soon). I'd seriously recommend this game to anyone just getting in to VR. Hopefully this is a taste of further things to come not from just this dev but others.

30414934.review:
This is one game I do not regret at all spending money on. There are only so many wave shooters you can play before you need a taste of something sweeter. Vanishing Realms is the cake, with the cherry on top.

I love the enviroments and spent an age just gazing up at the sky or celling. The game experience may be short but I had a blast from the opening screen right to the end. It's the little touches that I loved. That gold cup stood high up on a plinth. Grab a rock, knock the bugger down. Trophy trapped on a wall in a web, burn it free. I felt involved. In an early part of the game I was laying on the floor crawling past some axe's, much to my wife's amusement. The wand feels great to use, blocking attacks with your sword or shield is cool, but the bow and arrow for me is the stand out weapon in the game. It just felt right.

Sure it's not perfect. Combat feels a little simple. Definitely helps to have a large play area. Mine is fairly large at 2m x 4m and the 2m can cause movement issues. You will find yourself teleporting often just to get where you need to be, but please don't let that put you off. I have played in a 2m x 2m area before I relocated the vive and it still plays fine.

To sum up. Buy this game. If you don't enjoy the genre then walk around the area's and look about. Jaw dropping I feel. You may well of spent in excess of 2 grand for a dedicated pc and vr headset, what's £15 on top of that. Just get it.

30245778.review:
PROS:
Excellent game and world design give good immersion
Good balance of puzzles, combat and looting
Fun combat both melee and ranged with blocking mechanic
Fun puzzles/challenges that start simple and get harder
Devs seem to be committed to updating and improving
Possibility of open world map in the future has been talked about


CONS:
Bit lacking in the story department text only no real sotry
Short tutorial doesn't teach you much 
Game length needs to be longer or have path choices bit linear
Some of the AI enemies are simple to defeat unless in groups


This is a fantastic VR game and really show cases what the technology is capable of doing at the moment. If you have a nice powerful i7 and GTX 1080 up the supersampling in your Steam VR settings and it's super crisp. Even on my older card before I upgraded this was nice looking and fun to play.

This game really reminds me of the 80s & 90s TV kids game show Knightmare where a team of friends guided a 4th mate through a quest and lots of fun challenges in a computer generated world. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knightmare

There is a lot of immersion due to the cool scenery and sound effects and the dungeon setting is modeled very well indeed. I can only imagine in 5 years time the way VR is going we're going to have more games like this featuring multiplayer, playable classes and much bigger open worlds.

Vanishing Realms is essentially a dungeon crawl hack and slash game with combat, looting and puzzles there isn't any real story or character leveling though. You explore a vast dungeon/castle solving puzzles and collecting treasure which allows you to buy various weapons and armour along the way to help fight skeletons and other monsters. Combat is fun featuring melee and ranged but difficulty wise only a few of the enemies are hard.

Think Knightmare mixed with a little bit of Zelda and you have this game!

The combat features blocking and attacking in various ways like stabbing and slashing with range weapons as an option like bows. As I said the combat is not highly skilled by normal RPG standards but it's still very fun and engaging requiring timing to block or dodge attacks. I can only imagine what I must look like in my VIVE swinging my hand around to stab and raising my other hand to block with my shield. The standard enemies are simple enough to beat but the bosses and bigger ones prove more difficult. That said when you encounter more than one enemy at a time it keeps you on your toes.
 
This game has all the usual dungeon crawler puzzles and challenges to workout along the way. The fact the devs added climbing and different movement options recently has made the game better. I'd love to see character classes and more open world stuff added one day.

I initially downloaded a torrent copy but after my first 20 minutes I went and bought it and I am happy to support the developer if they make more games of this standard. The only thing I'll say it's not really a roleplaying game as the story is quite basic in the form of text it would be nice to have some narration perhaps in future updates and a bit more choice of where to go and explore in the form of different paths to complete the game.

I would defiantly say this is one of the best VR games around at the moment and I'm amazed it's early access it feels like a completed game. Some people have complained about play time but the price is just about right at £15.

Most people say this has an average 3-5 hours play time.

Schwertkämpfe gegen Skelettkrieger sind zum Beispiel ein echtes Highlight und auch andere scheinbar belanglose Spielmechaniken, wie das entzünden von Feuerschalen mit einer Fackel, das Bogenschießen oder das Gewinnen von Rohstoffen mit einer Spitzhacke werden durch die Bewegungscontroller der Vive zu einem Erlebnis. Bleibt nur zu hoffen, dass aus dem Early Acess-Titel irgendwann ein fertiges und vollwertiges Spiel wird. Schon jetzt eines der besten VR-Erlebnisse.

30214733.review:
I generally don't have issues running Vive games with Oculus, this is one of the rare ones that I do.

A lot of other rift users have reported the same issue of tracking degredation over time which I believe is a call the game is making for updated information repeatedly to vserver, eventually vserver jams which carries over the game and causes that to jam as well.

I won't be rating the game any lower because of that as the 10 minutes I can play each time are quite a good example of why you SHOULD have support (the same reason I won't be asking for a refund) but please do look at converting what you DO have to the Oculus native system engine wise and let the game decide which to call on it's own ;)

Keep up the good work and know that there are a bunch of us Rift users looking to play your game when you get us over to it!

30213682.review:
This is a game that you need to own. It's a refreshing breath of something new in the otherwise wave shooter saturated VR market. If you own a vive, you should own this game.

The combat is really fun, the world immersive, and the game makes you want to keep playing. Even at this early stage combat feels fairly well matched if you are up for a fight (rather than just picking people off with your bow). The art style is well suited for the game.

Now, it is an early access game and as such some bugs are to be expected. I haven't run across anythign game breaking yet, but expect the odd hit that shouldn't have hit, and the occasional platform that is accessible that shouldn't be. The game is also a little shy for content, but the developer is active and I don't think any more could be expected for an early access game.

J'ai terminé il y a quelques mois Vanishing Realms sur une note un peu mitigée. L'expérience était à la hauteur, mais je trouvais que l'on arrivait trop rapidement à la fin. Le jeu ne semblait en effet qu'un gros tuto (acquérir la technique de déplacement, du combat à l'épée, du maniement du bouclier, de l'arc puis du pic), la partie jeu se terminant très vite.

Or, en le reprenant ces derniers jours, je m'apperçois que le contenu a été enrichi, des passages secrets, de nouvelles salles et énigmes à résoudre.

Tant mieux. Vu qu'il s'agit du meilleur RPG auquel j'ai joué en VR, c'est que du positif.
Les ennemis ont un petit côté cartoon que j'ai trouvé sympa. Sa gestion de l'inventaire à la ceinture était la première que je voyais aussi bien pensée (d'autres ont fait mieux depuis). Le jeu se raccroche à un scénario qui a le mérite d'exister, mais le jeu reste quand même principalement linéaire. Mais je me plais à chercher les pièces et autres objets de valeur, à combattre ces ennemis un peu balourds.

Les +
> ambiance
> inventaire intuitif
Les -
> durée de vie, même avec les ajouts récents
> ennemis un peu trop simples, même en mode hardcore.

30078119.review:
Hab das Game jetzt in grob 4 Stunden durchgespielt. Nun versuche ich meine Erfahrung so gut es geht zu beschreiben.
Vanishing Realms war eins der ersten VR Games das ich ganz durchgespielt habe im Rythmus 2Std Game/ Pause / 2Std Game.

Die Story

Die Story ist jetzt keine große Überraschung es orientiert sich halt an den guten klasischen Adventure/RPG Games. Untote und ein Held der gegen sie ins Feld zieht und versucht den König der Untoten nieder zu ringen. Man bekommt immer wieder Story und Gamplay wichtige Texte entweder per Sprachausgabe von Steinköpfen die an Wänden hängen, Gegnern oder aus Schriftrollen und Büchern.

Steuerung

Diese wird am Anfang ausreichend erklärt. Jedoch gibt es einige Aspekte die man selber erstmal im Game ausprobieren muss. Besonders positiv finde ich das Inventar was viel zum erleben des Spiels beiträgt. Schneller Wechsel der Waffen und auch gute Inventargröße. Das Teleportieren hilft gerade am Anfang sich an VR zu gewöhnen im Gegensatz zu Titeln wie Yore VR oder Onward. 
Die Motionsickness ist je nach Spieler bei Vanishing Realms abhängig. Mir machte es nach 2 Std nix mehr aus also eine 2/10 für Motionsickness. (Durch das Game wurde auch meine Motionsickness bei Spielen wie Onward besser also Trainingsgame falls ihr Motionsickness anfällig seid)

Spielerlebnis

es gibt viel zu entdecken in Vanishing Realms. Über Geheime Räume bis zu versteckten Gegenständen. Und sogar ein Schatzkarten Rätsel. Es gibt Spitzhacken zum Abbau von Material. Achivment Gegnestände. uvm.
Die Gegner sind unterschiedlich man muss sich einstellen. Es gibt "Standart Soldaten", "Hauptmänner" , "Zwischenbosse/Berserker", Und auch Heiler und Magier. Also für Abwechslung ist gesorgt. 

Gegner sind zwar meist wenig bewegungsfreudig vor allem die Standartgegner aber.... nach einigen Versuchen sie mit nem Bogen zu snipern waren ihre Ausweich Dashes 1a. Auch die Angriffscombos der "Hauptmänner" bleiben zwar relativ gleich aber sie haben 2-3 Moves die einen echt in Bedrängnis bringen. Also man brauch schon einen Gewissen Platz um auf die Angriffe zu reagieren. Ich würde die Spielzone definitiv auf 2 x 2 Meter einrichten. Sonst gibts bei stärkeren Gegnern wie z.B Berserker da ihr euch viel bewegt probleme das ihr irgendwo gegen klatscht.

Sound
Sehr stimmig. Es gibt keine Fehler wie fehlende Sounds oder Delays. Die Stimmen die verwendet werden passen sehr gut tragen gut zum erleben dieser Welt bei. 

Grafik

Finde sie erinnert mich vom Aussehen her an Torchlight. Finde sie aber sehr stimmig und passend es gibt 1-2 Sachen die mir aufgefallen sind wo man paar Probleme merkt aber im Gegnsatz zu anderen Early Access Titeln ist das echt zu vergeben. Die Gegner sind schön gestaltet wenn man den Stil mag Und auch Landschaftlich finde ich die Grafik ansprechend. Sonst hätte das Spiel es nicht geschafft mich volle 4 Stunden zu fesseln.

Fazit

Solides Early Access Spiel wenn man sich erstmal in VR zurecht finden muss und erstmal gucken will was die Spiele können. Die 19,99 € sind finde ich gerechtfertigt es kommen ja noch Episoden dazu. Und finde es gibt andere VR Games die Early Access sind und nen Haufen Geld verlangen aber ich finde ungerechtfertigt. 30 - 40 € für paar Level oder sogar nur eins ist ein wenig viel Übertreibung

Also klare Produkt Empfehlung.

29850257.review:
The 1980s were an exciting era when I powered up my PC with the video games Ultima, Bards Tale, and Might and Magic.  late nights and marathon play sessions with my brother through those fantasy adventures forging our heroic tales along the way. 
 
I did not realize it at the time but looking back I think that I had made a sort of deal with the developers of those games.  They were building something that we all desperatly wanted.  They were the first in an emerging technology and art form.   As expected the games were limited by the tech, rough around the edges, and simplistic in the delivery.  There needed a forgiving partnership that filled the hours with enjoyment.  I the consumer would contribute to the game as I played.  I would flesh out their stories, fill in the gaps and use my imagination to create things that were not there to imerse myself in the world they created.  

As I play Vanishing Realm I feel like this partnership is a chief requirement to my experience.  Vanishing Realm is once again the realization of a child of the 80s dream.  Like I was so many years ago I find myself needing to fill in the gaps and flesh out the world to make it work.  

Vanishing It is obviously a small project, in an emerging technology, by an indie developer.  As expected it is short in content, rough on the edges, and simplistic in the delivery.  If I left it there my sleep-deprived-UltimaIV younger self would die a painful death.  With the short comings aside this game is absolutly a thrill that I have been waiting for years to play.  It is everything I hoped a VR RPG could be, and sets the stage for so much more to come.  This game plucks the heart strings of my 80s inner child.  It is that dream of D&D on the computer and playing in a fantasy world turned into being inside the RPG game.

When I play vanishing realm I see the past, the present and the future at the same time and it is a glorious experience.  I gladly pay the money for what this game is, how it stirs my soul, and what it provides in a glimps to the future.

29793420.review:
Raid dungeons, battle undead, and gather loot in Vanishing Realms, a D&D themed room-scale virtual reality adventure. The backstory to this particular chapter involves some lost realm in dire need of exploring and an undead king that’s become a nuisance of some sort. Oh, and lots of skeletons.

Initially the game presents itself as a bit of a puzzle-solver but after some exploring and coin collecting you eventually get your first weapon and are plunged into combat. The sword swinging mechanic requires that you make short quick movements with your wrist or arm for the game to register it as an attack. The angle of attack matters as well since most enemies will parry or block your attacks if you swing into their defenses rather than waiting for an opening to strike. That isn’t to say that silly tactics like dual wielding swords and swinging wildly aren’t still feasible, but you will also take a lot of damage in the exchange.

Be forewarned that this particular VR title has a history of performance issues, many of which I resolved simply by disabling running processes (windows update is a big culprit) to get CPU usage down to under 20% and also setting the CPU priority of the program to high in the task manager. You will likely still see some significant FPS drops in certain areas but it will be way more manageable. Obviously having a cutting-edge rig (e.g. anything with components better than my older i5 and gtx 980) will also mitigate these issues and you can always check the community discussions if you are unsure.

Anyways, I’m glad to have stuck with this game after initially trying to refund it (for the aforementioned issues). It’s pretty fun and yet another good game for showing off what the vive can do since it features melee and ranged combat along with exploration and puzzle solving all in a very nicely detailed environment. I recommend it, but just make sure your system is up to spec first!

29781776.review:
Vanishing Realms is a really good demonstration of the power of VR. As a traditional hack-and-slash dungeon crawler this wouldn't merit more than a footnote. Basic dungeons, fairly limited amount of items and monsters and so on. However as a VR title this really shines. It's entirely different to dodge the fireball yourself. Or to succesfully block a skeletons upper strike to leave it open for a counter-attack when you have to actually swing both the shield and the sword. The full freedom to choose which weapons and/or tools to carry in your hands lets the player choose their own approach. And make mistakes.
The game benefits quite a bit from having a larger room-scale setup due to easier positioning and maneuvering.
In short, kind of hard to consider this an early access game. There is quite a bit more content here than in many "full release" VR games.
PS Careful with that torch.

29582113.review:
Because of the main mode of locomotion being the teleport and most hostiles take more than a few hits, Vanishing Realms give me the impression of what Legend of Grimrock should be in VR if incorporated nicely as a slow paced action fueled RPG.

Main concepts:
- Teleport
- Careful strikes of opponents wth more than a few hits
- Ai dodges attacks, reacts to your controller position but does not engage until in the vicinity of its combat area
(Main reason that gives you a sort of turn based RPG feel)
- Making slow paced/turn based concept to admire the scenery, ambiance and surrounding
- Progress and not free form based inventory, you collect them and fit into an inventory belt
- Puzzles are minor, its more of travelling, clearing zones and figuring out the entire chapter
- Traps, loot and quest items slow you down to appreciate the levels and design of the chapter

As a player of both Grimrock and Skyrim, this seems like a mash up of both. Not as hard core as either as you don't move per block as grimrock with hardcore puzzles nor do enemies come charging at you. You can dodge easily with well timed teleports thus the immersion of full rpg like skyrim is not there along with enemies only being triggered at their areas.

I think this is where vanishing realms shines, it knows the sacrifice it is taking, making gameplay as such, because it wants to deliver exactly what I described above and to be honest, I do prefer to have one RPG reflecting Legend of Grimrock more in VR, and this game is probably it if it had more levels, more intricate stories, more spells, more complex around the chapter puzzles, more bosses, more maps and the ability to combine at least one type of thing, say a rune/gem or crafting certain consumable items or even quest items, might as well add more diverse quest items. All the above is already promised for chapter 2, and the forth coming chapters, so I have no doubt the developers will continue to make it more towards Legend of Grimrock VR than Skyrim VR, which is what it should be.

If you are already a Legend of Grimrock fan and just joined the VR clan, this is definitely your go to before the dev adds more chapters for the fine tuned turn based action rpg that almost mimic systems like DnD into VR, it supports Vive and Oculus, I'm on experimental 360 2 sensors and have the common glitches you'd get from experimental setup, no diff from an oculus game in certain situations

29426725.review:
This is, without a doubt, the best VR game I've played. The art style is fantastic. The world is believable and charming. The combat is satisfying and engaging. I love the inventory system and feeling of searching for items in my pack. 

I've played RPG's since there were RPG's and for the first time, I feel like an adventurer on a quest. You don't just press a button to equip an item. You literally through your inventory pack and equip it in whichever hand you want. The enimies are well balanced and offer enough variation in their combat to keep it fun. 

What is most impressive to me about this game is how it didn't come from a big game company, but from what I can tell, just one developer. Which is probably my only gripe with the game and it isn't a real gripe at all. I want more content now! With just one dude and a dream building it, progress is slow but worth the wait.

If you haven't played this yet do yourself a favor and do so. There are lots of things going on here which will only get better in time. New games coming out in the future would be wise to copy some of the traits of this game and build upon them.

良質なアクションRPGです。
また、現時点で数少ない「完品」のVRゲームだと思います。
剣で切り付ける、魔法を操る、弓を射るVRゲームはたくさんありますが、これら全てがゲームの世界観と結びつき、没入感の高い高度なゲームシステムを構築しています。
盾と剣での戦闘においても、単品のソードゲームよりも敵のモーションが豊かで、臨場感に勝ります。

日本語化はされていませんが、それほど難しい謎解きはなく、辺りをぶらついていればなんとなく進んでいける難易度です。

29384562.review:
This game is one of the better VR games I have played so far.  It works good with the Oculus and Touch controllers if you have three sensors.  If you only have two it doesn't work well, and will crash frequently.  I think there is some bug with the game when it looses tracking which causes it to start stuttering and eventually crash.  Once I added a third sensor the problem cleared up. 

The game play is good.   Inventory location was a little awkward, but not too bad.  Interface is easy and intuitive.  Graphic and visuals are nothing spectacular but that is fairly typical with most VR games.  There are no deep story lines to this game, it is pretty much a hack and slash on rails.  My only gripe with the game is that it is short.  Once I got my environment setup and running good, it only took me one 2-3 hour session to complete.

This is a very nicely done elementary dungeon crawl.

Although simple enough for my kids to play, it provided slight challenges working out their puzzles at times.

Every game mechanics issue I have with dungeon crawls are still present.  Aka running back to the beginning in order to gain access to a weapons upgrade.  I mean it makes sense but just ends up being the player's waste of time in real life, which to me is more precious.

With that being said, it's a solid entry level dungeon crawl that I thoroughly enjoyed.  My son's 8 to 13 enjoyed themselves and we can't wait for episode ii to be released, hopefully through a game update as they finish this early access game.

29345260.review:
I've had my Vive for a little while now, and to be honest I'm a little bit disappointed in the games that are available at this moment. Most of the games I played (Job Simulator, Raw Data, H3VR, The Lab, Space Pirate Trainer) don't really feel or play like finished games, more like glorified tech demos. They're really fun for a little while, but after a few hours you get bored because you can't really sink your teeth in them. You don't get lost in their world like you would with a "proper" video game, like The Witcher, Tomb Raider, DOOM or Dark Souls. From all the VR games I played, Vanishing Realms feels the most like a complete game. There's a story, an art style, a world to explore, and game mechanics to master.

If you are looking for a "real" game in VR, this is the best one I played so far. However, I do have to say that it is kind of short. Even if you take your time to explore every nook and cranny, you'll be done in about 3 to 4 hours. I also recommend that you play on the highest difficulty setting, because it is quite easy.

VR(Vanishing Realms) includes various aspects of puzzles, exploration, and combat, and each aspect is done very well. 
On the note of combat, it has by far the best swordplay of any swordfighting VR game I've played so far, especially in hardmode. 

6 months after initial EA release, we still only have the first two chapters with little news of any updates. However, it's still worth the price.

I am a Rift user, full room scale, but unfortunately banished ( by my wife ) to a rather smallish room for VR. 3 Sensor setup, all USB 3.0 no tracking issues, no disconnect issues. Due to the small size of my VR room I have to make smallish teleports to position myself to pick many things up… but that is my issue, not the games issue.

Ok Vanishing Realms: Impressive, truly, I am blown away by how good this is, I have not completed it yet, I am old and tire easily, can only play for 15 min or so at a time. Tracking is excellent, I have not had any of the issues others have reported. No freezes, no crashing.

Graphically the game is simply beautiful, stylized, but stays true to itself in style, it is easy to suspend disbelief and feel like you are actually there. I am past the huge skeleton with the spiked ball and chain, and have been mining for gold, trying to get enough to afford that wand ( as to how far in I am )

I would gladly have paid $20 for what I have passed already, and will jump at the opportunity to purchase more chapters if they are created. It is the little things that make it so immersive, the fact that hitting a skeleton on his Helmut, or shield does little to no damage, the fact you can parry, they way you can burn straw, or a curtain, the way small things are hidden. Easily one of my top VR experiences now, this is the kind of thing we have been wanting in VR

Hope someday for direct Touch support, but even without that, it is truly worth every penny and more.

Fantastic job

29140658.review:
