29135521.review:
Premise:
The epitome of what I wanted to see in a skill-based RPG in VR.  Amazing!

Graphics are crisp and well-defined.
The game itself has some puzzle elements, but nothing too complicated.  (E.G. Figure out how to get to a treasure, Find a key, figure out a riddle, etc)
Skill-based fighting 
- Melee: If your opponent swings high, you block or parry directly on their blade or duck.  Try to counter when you can see something open or just wait for the opportune time
- Ranged:  Using a bow and arrow feels really natural, there's no hiccups trying to grab the bow or nock an arrow, it's simply draw, aim and loose.  Having a ranged battle involves doing some ducking and moving or using short teleports between cover.
- Magic:  Not really implemented (at the time of this review) beyond a wand you'll have to buy during your travels.  It operates much the same as a fired explosive following an arced trajectory.
Great ambiance and fitting mood for the area you're in.
The ending really made you feel like you accomplished something.  Granted, right now there is only one chapter to the game (rite of steel), but it's a pretty long one!
Switching between weapons was a bit cumbersome at times since you have to look down at your belt while you fumble for your weapon.  In a few situations where you're surprised, that's nearly a death sentence.
Combat difficulty scaled as you play through the chapter.  Their moves became more complicated and faster with less hints at which way they would swing.  Overall it was still fairly easy if you have a shield.  Multiple enemies without a shield is pretty much a death sentence.

This is the type of game we dreamed about as kids.  I hope the next chapter is as exciting and fun!

29135347.review: Best time I've had in VR.

The display was mirrored to a projector so we could "peanut gallery" the current player.
It was sadly similar to the Vive sales videos, I feel a bit dirty.

Ages ranged from 18 to 60+ - including some people that "Don't like video games" (they played 2 hours straight)

There are complaints in the reviews  about no locomotion (I would like that option too.)
However,  I noticed "blinking" was easy to pick up for people who have never used VR. 
Plus there were no comments about sickness, despite some New Year cheer being served..

Really looking forward to more adventures, well worth the price.

Great job, I think it's a defining VR experience if you are an old school dungeon crawler.

P.S. Love the inventory.

29025705.review:
Just finished chapters 1 & 2. Some thoughts:

Pros:
- Blocking attacks with the shield or parrying with a sword / hammer / axe is a lot of fun. You can even pretend you're Legolas and dodge arrows, which is really cool. You can also block arrows, which will stick to your shield for a while.
- Enemies are fairly varied. There are lots of variations for the standard sword & shield guys.
- The one really big boss fight towards the end is fun, and will get your blood pumping.
- You not only get melee weapons, but bows and a magic wand as well.
- You can finally mine rocks in VR :P
- You can dual wield swords, or a combination of other weapons.
- There is a 2-handed axe, which is interesting to use.

Cons:
- Swordplay is not nearly as tight as it could be. Actually landing hits on enemies can be.. Hit and miss. Their hitboxes are pretty bad, in my opinion. When you get used to it and don't flail about like an idiot though (like I tend to do) - it's not too bad.
- Maybe I just suck, but using the bow well is very hard. I'll add that I have no problems whatsoever in the archery demo in The Lab (played that one quite a bit).
- Teleportation. I personally dislike this; probably because I don't get motion sick when playing games with analog movement.
- Backtracking is a pain because of the teleportation movement system. Oh, how I wish devs would implement alternative control schemes. The touch pads on the Vive controllers would be just fine for moving forwards and back. The Oculus Touch controllers are probably even better for this.

Summary (TLDR):
If you like RPG's and have a VR headset, you should probably buy this. It's worth the asking price, even though it's a short game. If you have patient friends, you can even demo this to them - and they'll probably love it. It has its fair share of problems, but these are easy to look past. I'd give this one a 7,5/10.

28911659.review:
From the moment you start the game to how intuitive the "interface" is, this game is both beautiful, immersive, fun and awesome.  If you wanted to experience an adventure, solve puzzles and fight monsters, this is the game for you.

Sound/Graphics:
To me, I love the style and how everything in the game looks.  They style is kind of cartoony and it works really well for this game.  There is a "level" or area inside of a crypt that is flooded and from the water dripping to the echos of distant noises plus the need to use a torch to help with the darkness, this game really hits the mark.  In areas where you are exploring outside, you can hear the crickets chirp whil looking at the dark moon light things up.  It is a beautifully well done game and an amazing VR experience

Interface:
The developer really hit a home run on this one.  From the moment I jump inot the game, everything is very intuitive and self explainitory.  There is a tutorial level to get you going for new users but I would love to see this type of interfacing as the norm for adventure games.  Pulling items from your inventory, dropping and movement is extremely simple and really helps you to forget that you are in a game.  The simplicity really helps with immersion combined with the sound and the graphics, I really felt like I was in this world, even after taking off the VR headset.  Well done!

Gameplay:
I have read people compare this to Zelda type games, which is one way to describe it.  the way I see it is, if you took an old school point and click adventurgame like Lucas Arts or the old Sierra games, converted it to a 3D VR space and added additional elements of combat, this is Vanishing Realms.  It was so fun to play (I spent about 3 hours from start to finish trying to explore every nook and cranny) there are so many "hidden" things to do in this game from looking in the hollow part of a log to find treasure to solving riddles and finding solutions to progress to other areas.  This aspect is very immersive and fun.  I caint wait to see more from this game and I hope other adventrue games follow suit with Vanishing Realms

Combat:
Combat is split into two categories, melee and ranged and I must say, I was pretty impressed by the combat and the AI.  In melee, you may get a few hits in if you start randomly swinging at a monster, but they block, set back and move out of your way so you can't use that as a go to strategy.  The different monsters do have patterns and once you figure it out (by watching how they hold their sword, and if you react quick enough, you can easily defeat the monsters.  It takes time to learn this, makinc one on one combat a joy... that leads to much more challenging scenarios when you face multiple opponents at the same time.  You really need to look and block and move and avoid being surrounded in order to win otherwise they will chop you up like diced tomatoes ;) this is where you need group based combat strategies... i.e. move arround your opponents and do not get surrounded... you can also use other enemies to help kill each other.  I was fighing a Giant skeleton, who has a ball and chain type weapon with a few other skeleton creatures facing me.  I would manuver myself between a smaller skeleton and the swining ball and chain from the giant one, and have him crush my opponents for me. It was fun and you have to try it :) you can also pick between dual wield, sword and shield and two handed weapons, which really change up how you play and works great in different scenarios.

Ranged combat is well though out and I really felt like I was pulling back on a bow.  If you try to shoot monsters from a distance, they will move or block and, while you have unlimited arrows, it can be pretty challenging to bring a creature down that is protected and is moving out of your way.  Using the terrain around you to protect from incoming projectiles was another fun and tactical way to deal with enemies from a distance that were shooting back at you.  I know I spent more time on melee combat but doing things like shooting apples from a tree, cutting wires with my arrows to give me access to a bridge or shooting pesky mage ghosts as fireballs streak past me... this was insanley fun.

Over all:
Get this game, you will not be disappointed :)

28895533.review:
Great example of what future RPGs can build upon for VR. Took me about 2.3 hours to complete on Classic difficulty, and I fully expect to go back and play it again on Hard once it is out of Early Access and Steam Achievements are implemented.

Pros:
- Enemies will learn as you fight them. Hit an enemy swordsman 2-3 times with your bow and arrow, and they will make sure to dodge/parry the next time you shoot at them, forcing you to change strategy and fight them differently. 
- Higher difficulty enemies will utilize chain attacks and attempt to strike you in your week spots, keeping you on your toes and parrying between strikes.
- Great variety of environments to explore.
- Progressive introduction of new weapons/enemies.

Cons:
- $20 for a 2-3 hour game is a bit high. However I can understand that until VR becomes more mainstream, this is needed to offset development cost. Fortunately, I was able to buy this on sale.

28841838.review:
This was the second VR game I had purchased after Space Pirate Simulator, and was one of the better first forays into the RPG adventure side of things (the other one being Spell Fighter, a clunky free vr game)

What did I like:

The art style visually pleasing and doesn't get in your face.

Sword and shield mechanics feel fluid, but with some issues (see below)

Archery was clean, for the most part, but also had some issues (see below)

Most of the environment is interactable. There's a section in game where there were a number of ore clusters around, and I was wondering if I would be able to mind them later on. Sure enough, a few areas later I found a few pickaxes.

Puzzles were challenging, but didn't make me want to take the headset off and quit.


What I didn't like:

Presently in game, there's an auto-pause feature. This may have been more of an issue with my cobbled settup, but I was experiencing the auto-pause going off a lot during combat and exploration, despite me not going out of sight of my base stations. I tried turning it off, but whenever I did go out of range of my base stations I got pwnt by the enemies.

Combat is good for the most part, but hit detection needs a lot of work. I managed to complete both chapters, but not without combat grinding to a halt because of auto-pauses, or constantly having to flail and reposition due to the auto-pause throwing my character out of position, and rendering me unable to hit anything.

Call me a noob, but I was having extreme issues with archery at long range. There's a section where you need to fight a skeleton wizard, a skeleton cleric, and a skeleton juggernaught. Attacking the fire wizard or the juggernaut doesn't work because the cleric  heals them. Trying to dodge fireballs and hit the cleric repetedly was almost impossible due to how archery works. I wish there was a proper sight on the bow, or at least something to assist with aim.

Later on in game you have the opertunity to gain a two-handed axe as a weapon. While it deals good damage, I found myself going back to my battleworn sword that was dealing less damage due to the outright clunkyness of the mechanics. Again, this may have been an issue with my settup rather than a game issue.

Inventory management for weapons was something that I almost tore my hair out at. Trying to swap from sword to axe, or vice versa, was a trial in patience, since if you click on the axe with your sword equiped, it causes them to stack rather than swap. I ended up getting hit a lot because I was trying to swap to my sword, and ended up stacking it on top of the axe, leaving my unarmed in my main hand, rather than swapping to the proper weapon.



All in all, Vanishing Realms is a good game, but it does suffer from issues that can be solved with a bit more polish, and a bit more work setting up your play area.

28840928.review:
This has been my favorite VR game to play so far. The ambiance in the game makes you feel like you're really alone in a dark magic world. A big part of that feeling comes from the ambient noises and music. Deep rumbling, droning noises, and occasionally noises from monsters in rooms nearby as you creep around. It's not a horror game but it will make you jump sometimes as a skeleton pops out of something unexpectedly.

The combat in the game is fun even though getting used to teleporting in combat is a little weird at first. I especially liked the enemy arhcers because it was unnerving seeing their arrows flying right at your face. I liked the rush as your instinct kicked in to prevent you from getting an arrow shot through your face because your brain didn't know it was only VR. I would have liked the enemies to be a bit more agressive in chasing me. I haven't tried the hard mode yet, maybe they do then?

Mining wasn't something I was expecting to see in this game but was pleasantly surprised. There is a lot of future potential here. Resource gathering and crafting would be cool. Another interesting concept to see in VR was the destroyable object: burning or smashing things to find hidden items. Lastly, some items were in plain sight but required solving a puzzle or finding a clever way to knock it down. I found myself picking up candles and throwing them at the ceiling knocking down goblets. Lots of fun.

Looking forward to new expanded content soon.

28825018.review:
[h1]Vanishing Realms[/h1] est le jeu VR le plus interresant de ma bibliotheque. J'ai ete impressionné par les possibilités qu'il offre.
Vous serez amenés Esquivez des pieges,rampez, parrez des attaques, comprendre le paterne des mobs. j'ai meme reussi à me perdre dans le donjon car j'avais egaré ma torche.
La gestion de l'inventaire est originale et pratique (deux sac d'inventaires, objets de quetes, objets courrant, ainsi que les slots d'armes) il suffit simplement de baisser la tete pour les voir apparaitre à la ceinture.

Prise en main: les controleurs permettent aisément le déplacement via un systeme de télèportation, d'interagir avec l'environement (torche..., cranes...,pommes...) mais aussi avec les armes (épées, haches, arcs,batons de sorcier)

Coter graphisme, c'est pas la folie, pas de flou ou de probléme de motion sikness, les textures sont d'inspiration cartoon (World of Warcraft, Torchligt).
Le bestiaire est assez pauvre, j'ai croisé 5 monstres differents, et seulement 3 environnements.
Niveau ambiance sonor on est loin du Hans ZIMMER, mais ca reste correcte. 
Le seul regret le manque de contenu .*Early Accces*

 
[h1] "J'ai toujours revé etre dans la peau d'un aventurier, me balader dans un donjon et fritter du demons."	[/h1]
Immertion complete reussit.

28756682.review:
Put simply, this is a truly amazing and super fun game for VR.

I won't comment on the full content, as to me this is part of the experience while playing this game which represents the most you can expect. And that's the first and only negative aspect I see for this game: The overall play time you'll get for paying 20€. The first playthrough (Nearly non-stop, I just had to sleep and eat something on occasion..) provided me with nearly 4 hours of fun. A few euros less and you'll get a very polished and well made game for your bucks. Since I got this game during Steam's Winter Sale it cost me 14€ which looks like a reasonal price to me. But this is nitpicking. Paying more than that just helps the developer to provide us with a third chapter.

And this what I'm looking for. The third chapter. Or put simply, again, MOOAR content!

- I want to smash bigger and more challenging creatures (Though, I have yet to play this game on "Hard" and fighting against multiple opponents IS already challenging!).
- I want more stories which evolve the same way as the one from the first chapter. (And please, again using rimes which match the atmosphere so well!)
- I want more (bigger?) items to throw around, maybe even ones you can utilize in combat. (Throwing a bottle at the enemy and then set him on fire using a torch...)
- I want more magic. One wand is not enough. (Though there's magic, after all!)

For those who still hesitate:

- You really need the required play space. I played the game on a 3.2mx1.7m space and if I had not only a couch which limits me to 1.7m but a solid wall I guess I already had to buy a new motion controller after the first fight. If not after the first 1 vs 1, then definitely after the first 1 vs 2 engagement.
- The graphics are not what you'll see in the usual games today. It's rather a more modern Spyro or any similar jump'n'run from the past, graphic wise. But it's not the graphics what makes truly great games great! And that's even more the fact for this game.
- The teleportation system works very well. It's not like in other games or "demos" and limits you how far you can teleport in a nice way. I can't properly describe it, but it just works and does not feel that different than using your own feet. And since the required play space is already fairly big, you'll have enough chances to use your own feet nonetheless.
- It's VR. Put simply. ;-)

I can't await chapter three, four, five, ......

28736449.review:
I've been on Steam since it began and in all that time I don't think I've written a single review.  I probably should have for a few games but this one basically compelled me to write one. 

THIS GAME IS FREEKING AMAZING.  

Its what anyone who has been dreaming about VR gaming could hope for in a VR game.  

If this were a normal game it would be a very forgettable dungeon crawler several years out of date.  Its not though, its a true VR game with a excellent interface, responsive controls, puzzles which are not very hard but very interesting in VR, and the fact I can have a real sword fight with a armored skeleton is fantastic.  I was surprised I even had to properly swing to get a two handed axe to work right and I'm blocking with the shaft intuitively.  

I also learned a valuable lesson.  Unlike a regular game, its totally not worth picking up every gold coin on the ground and smashing EVERY pot or box.  I only just quit playing because after several fights with the 2h axe, I was getting a bit sweaty, and I'm not an out of shape gamer. 

Basically if you own a Vive, you MUST get this.  I'm not sure why it didn't show up for me in a VR search on steam, (found it via google), this should be shipped with the Vive as a package its so good.

Side note, my room is pretty small, the Vive minimum, and I'm under the recommended size for this game but the games UI is good enough that its never been an issue. 

If I could make one small suggestion, I would allow for drawing/sheathing motions from the back and hip for swords, bows, etc.  

Anyways GET THIS GAME.

When I show off my Vive to friends, this is the game everything else leads up to. 

Vanishing Realms is the single best VR game available today. It's got everything I want in a VR game: room-scale support, great visuals, realistic sound, melee combat, ranged combat, strategy, unique environments, and so much more. 

The combat moments are intense, but not scary. I love that there are hidden objects all over the world. And the pacing is just right.

28616691.review:
One of, if not THE, best VR game I have played to date.  The combat seems simplistic at first, but is the perfect pace given the control scheme and generally clunkiness of current VR tech.  As with most VR games the kernel of something better is here and I hope this becomes a template for future games.  Unlike most VR games, this one doesn't rely on gimmicks.  It feels like a super simplistic dungeon crawl game, that on a normal PC interface would get 1 out of 10 stars, but modified controls to VR and it's easily 9 out of 10.  Nothing gets 10 out of 10 unless it cooks me dinner.

I don't like the angle the shield is held at, but I got used to it fast enough, and the combat is fluid without worrying about punching my desk if I get too close to the room boundaries.  Is there much replay value?  Probably not.  Is this the game to introduce people to VR with?  Definitely not, given the very slow learning (thankful for it) curve at the start.  But it's definitely one of those good intermediate experiences.

28540471.review:
I was concerned that this would be another glorified tech demo, as these early VR games often are, but far from it. This is a great game, and starting to show the twinklings of what VR games could offer in the future. Room for improvement? Yes. Time and money well spent? Definitely.

(constructive) criticism: 

1) The checkpoint system is not entirely intuitive. I left a chest to come back to later, and it was gone when I returned (apparently because my progress marked that section as 'cleared' in the save or something?)  It was never quite clear what would be saved and what wouldn't.

Ideally I'd like to be able to save whenever I want (VR sessions in particular often need to be much shorted than 'normal' PC gaming).

2) Items were not where I left them in bags when I restarted. A small issue, but would prefer if things stayed in the bag slot where I left them.

Keep up the good work!

28479023.review:
TL:DR - Its a enjoyable VR title that will suck you in you for 2hrs if you're willing to pay £7.50/hr to do something you enjoy then why not try this.

I have time to read - A really good game. I wish I had played it before Arizona Sunshine, then I would have rated it as an excellent game. Playtime approx 2hrs and I don't think I missed much (got all the chalices and shot half the apples off the trees)

Although the gfx are cartoon there is a lot of good stuff in this game. Looting, Mining and setting fire to just about everything that looks like it will burn. The story is good and well thought out and the devs have turned a dungeon crawl into something compelling to play for 2hrs. The AI is not completely stupid as in other sword fighing titles. They back off, have a variety of attacks, dodge arrows and even push you back if you get too close (Bone Hulk). So all in all, good. As for the fighting, be careful you don't need to swing wildly and well timed, aimed strikes will enable you to take out your opponents quicker and with ease. The bow/arrow are good and the collision detection is excellent. The two handed poleaxe is... well, a little unwieldy as you would expect a 2H poleaxe. If you keep good distance its fine, but lacks the precision of the sword.

I would like to see the devs expand this to include some spellcraft (casting runes in order to throw magic) and maybe multiplayer co-op.

* SPOILER ALERT BELOW *




The only down side I found was that, as a cautious fighter, I entered most large areas with caution, the mobs spawn and I can then pepper them with arrows from range and they didn't advance on me. In the show down with the king I took out all the mobs and half the kings health from just inside the door way with my bow/wand. Note to devs: Maybe don't allow me unlimited arrows. Put a quiver size of 50 arrows and allow me to collect from fallen enemies. That way I have to be more tactical in my engagement with the mobs.

Also the wand is OP it is basically a RPG (Note: The only time I died in the game was when I blew myself up with the wand).

If you are held up on the price tag, I can asure you it is absolutly worth a twenty dollar bill.

28477952.review:
VR Review für die HTC-Vive

Nun muss ich doch einmal sagen: Ich habe mich in mein erstes VR-Spiel verliebt. Wegen der Hoffnung auf solche Spiele habe ich mir eine VR-Brille zugelegt. 

Hier werden die Möglichkeiten von VR in tollen Situationen aufzeigt, an welche ich noch immer zurückdenken muss. Z.B. wenn man sich zum ersten mal bei einem PC Spiel dabei ertappt, wie man sich auf den Boden legt, um durch tödliche Fallen hindurchzurobben und einen Schatz zu bergen oder sich kurz aus der Deckung herauswagt, seinen gespannten Pfeil abfeuert und wieder hinter der Ecke versteckt. 
Bei schwereren Gegnern kommt man tatsächlich außer Puste und turnt wie ein Irrer durch das Wohnzimmer, um Schlägen auszuweichen und eigene zu platzieren. 
Das alles ist eingebettet in eine handgebaute wundervoll atmosphärisch düstere Welt, welche sowohl Innen- als auch Außenareale bietet, die  liebevoll gestaltet wurden und erst durch das Roomscaling richtig zum Leben erwachen. Die Grafik ist hübsch anzusehen und wirkt sehr immersiv. 
Im Kampf gegen die verschiedenen Gegnerarten hat man unterschiedliche Waffen, welche man nach und nach gegen gesammeltes Gold eintauschen kann, das an den unterschiedlichsten Orten versteckt ist in Form von Münzen, Pokalen und Edelsteinen. 
Gesteuert wird das Ganze mit den Vive-Controllern, wobei jeder Controller einen Arm darstellt, sodass man beispielsweise Schwert und Schild halten kann, oder eben beispielsweise einen beidhändigen Bogen. 
Wenn man es sich einfach machen will, dann kann man Gegner recht mühelos mit dem Bogen ausschalten, da die Gegner eine schlechte Wegfindung haben und sich quasi überhaupt nicht an den Spieler annähern. Daher entwickelt das Spiel seine wirkliche Stärke im Nahkampfsystem, wenn man Gegner mit dem Schild oder Schwert pariert und dann zum Gegenangriff auf ungeschützte Stellen ausholt, oder den Gegner umtänzelt und von der Seite angreift. Die Gegner greifen zur Zeit relativ langsam an, was dennoch sehr viel Spaß bereitet. 
Seit dem letzten Update gibt es jedoch einen Hardcore Modus, welcher dafür sorgen soll, dass die Gegner den Spieler verfolgen, schnelller attackieren, Hiebe gezielt parieren und Combos einsetzen. Getestet habe ich das bisher noch nicht. Außerdem wird das Spiel durch Updates um neue Areale erweitert, welche auchim normalen Modus verfügbar sind. 

Die Sendeboxen sollten für dieses Spiel gut ausgerichtet sein, damit sie die Controller auch in geduckter Haltung und an möglichst jeder Ecke des Spielbereichs einfangen können, da sonst die Verbindung abbrechen kann. Den vom Spiel voreingestellten automatischen Pause-Modus für diesen Fall kann man im Spielmenü deaktivieren, was ich jedem empfehlen würde, da die Controller in der Regel sofort wieder gefunden werden und man meistens nichts davon mitbekommt. Die Präzision im Kampf ist beeindruckend, sodass man wirklich das glaubt die Wucht eines abgewehrten Schlages zu spüren. 
Die Fortbewegung geschieht mittels Teleportation oder freiem Bewegen im verfügbaren Raum. Das Teleportieren wirkt dabei nicht störend, Motion Sickness war bei mir ebenfalls kein Problem, wobei ich auch relativ unempflindlich dafür bin. 

Zum Spielumfang kann ich noch nicht viel sagen. Ich habe es noch nicht durchgespielt und zudem befindet es sich ja noch im Early Acces Modus. Dennoch bekommt man bereits jetzt ein toll ausgearbeitetes Spiel, welches manch bisher noch nicht erlebtes Spielgefühl aufkommen lässt und den Preis meiner Meinung nach vollkommen rechtfertigt. Wenn ihr also ein Spiel haben wollt, welches euch großartig in die Welt der VR-Spiele einführt, dann drückt jetzt auf den Kaufen Button.

28379768.review:
I'm fairly new to the Vive and VR in general. Being a fan of RPGs, all signs pointed to Vanishing Realms as being the game of choice. Several minutes in and I wasn't disappointed. This immersive environment, while having a slightly cartoonish, Dragon's Lair-type quality, was extremely fluid and believable. While it doesn't have the same level of interactivity of games like ES:Skyrim, there is enough to keep you conscious of your environment (it's easy to set your floor on fire if you carry that torch too low!).  

I was extremely skeptical of the system of movement (teleporting) at first. Quickly I realized that with even a marginal play area, the mechanics worked very well. Being in the habit of smashing every container in site and wrecklessly grabbing every item in site with a mouse point or controller, the realistic action of picking up every item/coin/treasure and placing it in a "pocket" added a fun level of realism that made me appreciate the difficulty of being a "hero". 

Combat is simplistic, and yet precise all at the same time. There is a variety of weaponry, but I was fairly disappointed that there were no real physics or damage differences (that I was aware of) based on the weapon type (bashing hammer damage vs. slashing sword damage). I found the ability to duck and dodge while conducting archery combat to be extremely entertaining. The enemies become a little simplistic once you've gained some familiarity with the system, but the combinations present a challenge and keep things fresh.

The game has an intensity to it, when entering unknown caverns and labyrinths, that is completely lost in standard PC/Console gaming. Peeking shyly around corners, uncertain as to what surprise may lurk there. The sweat of actual combat! Hacking and slashing at a horde and wondering if maybe retreat is the right decision!

Overall, I highly recommend Vanishing Realms! It's a quick playthrough and I'm anxious for additional content! The possibilities are incredibly exciting and worth the investment.

I bought this game but put off playing it for a while because the art is a little bland. I'm glad I finally fired it up yesterday. It has been my favorite VR experience so far. It was easy to get lost in the world.

Once you learn the control conventions the game uses, everything just works as you think it should. For example, the triggers grab. If I grab an item with the wrong hand (maybe I grab an item I want to throw with my off-hand), I just put the other controller on the held item and click that controller's trigger. It's a short but fulfilling experience. Highly recommended!

28257190.review:
I just finished the first chapter of Vanishing Realms and wanted to leave the developer some feedback...

First, my hardware specifications are:
   OS:  Windows 10 Pro
   Processor:  i7-4790 @ 3.60GHz
   RAM:  16 GB
   GU:  Radeon RX 480
   VR:  HTC Vive, Game Area 2m x 1.8m (Just Under Requirement)

I received my HTC Vive a few days ago and have, like many I suspect, gone into a frenzy downloading and trying out VR content.  I've had lots fun and been amazed with The Blue and delighted with Google Earth, as well as numerous other titles.  I am 100% sold on VR, and am excited to begin my own development for the Vive platform.  (I'm an old software developer by profession.)

One of the titles that kept popping up online when I searched for top rated VR content was Vanishing Realms.  I was hesitant at the price at first, however, as I've discovered that there is a lot of content that, quite honestly, isn't enjoyable.  But, I'm a big "sword & sorcery" fan and Vanishing Realms gets lots of good reviews, so I paid my $20.00 and...  Promptly forgot all about it.

A couple days later (yesterday, in fact) I was looking through my growing VR content library and saw that Vanishing Realms was in there.  I fired it up and put on the Vive headset.  That was a mistake...  I had a list of chores to do around the house and didn't get to any of them.

The first thing I noticed about Vanishing Realms was how polished it was, compared to other experiences I had sampled.  The Vanishing Realms menu system was very intuitive and responsive.  I often see some frame drops when using the Vive, but noticed none while playing Vanishing Realms.  I was worried that the somewhat "cartoon" (versus photo-realistic) graphics would detract from the experience, but I ended up really liking the graphics.  (The "monsters" were realistic enough to cause me to jump back in exclamation on more than one occasion!)  I'm afraid that trying to go too photo-realistic with the graphics would result in frame loss which would ultimately detract from the virtual reality experience rather than add to it.

The game's audio is great and really helped define the game's atmosphere, whether it be the sound of wind blowing, the crackle of a torch, or the clang of sword on sword.

I was already somewhat familiar with the "blink" movement system from playing with The Lab, where it works very well.  It works equally well in Vanishing Realms, although, at times, it can make some combat "too easy."  An arrow coming at you?  Just blink over a bit to dodge it.  Fighting a nasty creature hand-to-hand?  Blink in, hit, and blink out.  During gameplay, to "even the odds," I tried to force myself not to blink too much in combat, as it seems like cheating in some way.

Speaking of movement, my play area is slightly smaller than the required 2m x 2m (I'm at 2m x 1.8m or so).  This did hamper my ability to reach certain items -- I would have to physically back up to the edge of my play area, and then blink closer to the object to be able to reach it.  This isn't the fault of the developer, however, and I am enlarging my play space which, I suspect, will solve this issue.  Also related to my smaller than required play space, sometimes, in the heat of "battle," I would step out of bounds which paused the game, causing a brief "disruption" of the virtual reality play experience.

I really like the inventory system in Vanishing Realms.  I like that it takes a moment to fumble around switching weapons in the face of an enemy -- it's much more realistic than just clicking a button on a control pad to switch from bow to sword.

As mentioned previously, I paid just at $20 for the game.  After playing the first chapter I consider my $20 very well spent.  When compared to the cost of going to see a movie (which lasts only a couple of hours), the cost for Vanishing Realms appears to be a bargain.  I would be willing to pay for additional chapters and/or expansions upon my completion of the game.

All in all, I don't have many complaints regarding Vanishing Realms.  Sure, I wish there was MORE (more levels, more monsters, more scenes, etc.), but, again, the game is only $20 (compared to $60 I've spent for Xbox One games).  I also wish that the game was more difficult, but I understand that it needs to be accessible to a large audience and not just hard-core "swashbucklers" like me.  As it is, I know that my 11-year old son will enjoy the game without getting frustrated that he is getting killed every scene. 

All in all, I highly recommend the game and can't wait to play the next chapter.  I will also be keeping an eye out for updates and additional titles from the developer.

28121849.review:
This game is undoubtedly the best VR experience I've had thus far.

Pros:
-Beautiful Zelda/WoW inspired graphics
-The combat feels amazing and exhillerating (Fun swordplay, bows, magic)
-Parry system is really cool
-In-game achievements add some replayability
-Physically jumping up to grab apples off of trees is more fun than you'd imagine.

Cons:
-Longer than most titles out there, but still relatively short
-Enemies become predictable
-Anything less than 16gb of RAM will give you some stuttering in a couple areas, although still playable and relatively isolated.

Tip:
-Given that there is a fair bit of moving around in this game, the screen automatically pauses for you to move back to the center of your play area so that you don't slam into a wall. This can be disabled, but I highly advise against it.


Overall, a must have title if you own an HTC Vive.

27900016.review:
This game is amazing.  You get to use bows, shields, swords, two-handed axes, and there's an awesome inventory system to store this stuff.  Chapter one was fantastic.  There was a really involved map and story that unfolded as you played, and the pacing was excellent.  It even got darker as I played (figuratively and literally), which I really liked.

I was really looking forward to chapter two, however, but it was not what I expected at all.  Where chapter one was like reading a book, chapter two was quite literally "kill these guys really fast" with no story to it at all.  There was a small arena on the same small map, and I was teleported back to the same area for every wave.  Felt very arcadey and really broke the immersion.

27606641.review:
At 2.5-ish hours, Vanishing realms might seem short. However, it contains a lot of glimpses into what a full scale RPG might look like. Vanishing Realms is packed with small little puzzles, interactive environments, and encounters. Fighting feels clunky at the start, but much more fluid after a few encounters. At one point, I was parrying one enemy with a sword, and another with a shield. The  two-handed battle axe and bow, are an absolute joy to wield.

I haven't tried hard mode yet at this point, but I'd like to see slightly more responsive AI. For most encounters. It's very easy to lure enemies to fight them one at a time. I'm sure this is a design descision, but I'd take Assasin's creed style circling over enemies just standing still. 

If you've got the money to try it, and are interested in seeing how a dungeon crawler would feel in VR, give it a go!

It was hard to put down, but my shoulders where getting tired from firing tons of arrows.  They have updated it as promised.  It has a lot to pffer for a little game.  I highly recommend it for the Vive.

27563964.review:
In a sea of wave shooters - Vanishing Realms is a welcome gem.

I consider Vanishing Realms a must have for VR today, especially for anyone who enjoys classical RPG's.

pros:
- art direction is perfect, looks great!
- world interaction a plenty, you will be smashing and burning to find coins hidden in just about every nook and cranny
- combat done very well, every battle feels intense and important 
- locomotion is designed for all users, teleportation with a 'stamina' style mechanism to prevent moving too far too fast
- inventory is the best ive seen, VR or flat, items go in your belt. simple 
- you hit rocks with a pickaxe 

cons (I struggled to find any real cons here):
- If you are used to open-world, this fairly linear experience might not satisfy (but there is plenty of exploring to do)
- some very minimal narrative - leaves you feeling a little bit 'aimless' in why exactly you are exploring this dungeon/world
- I've not yet finished it but replayability might be low
- no other method of locomotion for those who prefer 'walking' not teleporting

10/10 - must have

27561701.review: I finally got to experience a dungeon like I was really there! I want more! I prefer floating locomotion vs. teleportation, but this did not take away from the immersion. AWESOME stuff! Can't wait to continue the adventure!

Games like Vanishing Realms is why I purchased VIVE VR. Immersive, fun, and challenging - but VERY playable. VR is young and what we are seeing now is like PONG was in arcade games. Vanishing Realms (initials VR...nice) is a glimpse into the future. I can't wait to see what happens with VR! BTW We need more RPGs! 

As a community, I hope we review all the VR titles and hardware. What is cool (‘cuz VR is COOL) or just trying to cash in on the wave -  share our views. And share productively as to move out the junk and promote good stuff. Vanishing Realms is well worth the price. I am having great fun with Vanishing Realms and feeling like spending $800 on a VR system was OK. We need MORE like this. More well done RPG titles. 

This is my opinion and yours may be different. Thanks for reading.
Peace.

关于这款游戏，喜欢的朋友可以关注一下我的游戏实测哦~还是值得推荐的哦

http://www.bilibili.com/video/av7176709/

关于这个款消失的国度，整体来讲是不错的，我想从3各方面来说：
1.游戏的画面：游戏画面很清晰，没有卡帧的情况，游戏的沉浸感也是很棒的；
2.游戏设置方面：这是一款冒险解密类游戏，前期你可能会觉得没有太大的意思，需要找各种东西去解锁，还要存钱买箭，但是当你到后期的时候，你就会发现会有格斗，厮杀的场面，尤其在和怪物的打斗，还是很需要技巧的，总体来说还是比较比错的；
3.游戏本身：这款游戏刚开始的时候会让你觉得无聊，所以个人建议可以初始带一点轻武器类的，让玩家边打怪边解密就不会显得前面太单一，这样玩家的沉浸感也会更好。
4.关卡的设置：在关卡的设置上面作者也是用心良苦，会让你在捡宝物的时候，突然受的攻击，真的是送你吃蜜枣又问你要钱的感觉啊！！！
不错，总体来说游戏还阿是值得推荐的！

Absolutely incredible. My first Steam review as a result. I just fell over trying to climb on a table that wasn't there. It's like living Knightmare from when I was a kid. This really hits a VR sweet spot. Aside from the main menu screen the UI is seamless and innovative, which is a must for an RPG.

This is more of an RPG lite. It does a small amount of things, but does them really well. The combat is pretty decent, at first you can feel a little overwhelmed, but as you recognise the patterns it becomes a fun timing puzzle. By the end you'll be cutting down foes left and right.

There was certainly more in here than I expected. I especially enjoyed the sense of exploration. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a more lengthy VR experience.

Graphics are pretty simple, but on this early generation of VR headsets it works really well. This will no doubt look dated in a year or so.

26716489.review:
I'm not exaggerating when I say that this game is the reason I bought the HTC Vive. I played this game for about an hour on a friend's HTC Vive, and it simply blew my mind.

If you grew up wishing you could feel like you were inside the worlds of Zelda or its like, then this game is for you. The controls are incredibly intuitive, using the growing standard for movement found in The Lab and other games. Combat and action are absolutely astounding. The controls are so responsive, and the mechanics of hitting and missing are so well executed, that it really feels like your physical skill makes a difference.

And don't even get me started about the archery. Ducking behind cover, and popping up to shoot arrows at your opponents is like a 8 year old's dream come true, finally, at 41.

And the environments are fantastic. The ambient sound is very well executed, and the art style is excellent and consistent.

I really have nothing bad to say about this game excpe that at the time of my playing, it was too short! Can't wait for more content like this.

26666379.review:
This is one of my favorite VR titles to date. Unfortunatley, there's not an immense amount of replayabilty, but there are in-game achievements to hunt for as well as updates (Still an early access title). Speaking of updates, the developer is fairly vocal about them, and that's always a good sign. They claim this game is 1.5 - 2 hours of gameplay. I'd say that's not accurate. It's more like an  hour if you're speed-running on easy, and more like 4 - 5 if you're playing seriously on hard. You could easily stretch that into 10 (or even 16+ like me) by going through and really exploring on hard. Read every drop of lore, upturn every rock and skull (sometimes there are suprises under there!), and just have a good time. This game is listening to feedback and really paving the way for what a VR adventure game should be.

If you like fantasy adventures, this is definitely for you. I felt like I was one of my favorite sword-swinging heroes!

26627432.review: This is a very good implementation of VR for a RPG game.  The graphics are kinda a mix between realism and WoW like textures.  I played it for 3 hours and I don't think I am very far in the game.  There is quite a bit of content.  While I did not find the game too difficult, fighting the mobs got my heart racing.  I tried to play it like Skyrim where I would shoot mobs at a very long distance.  I do say these are smarter than the skyrim ones because after they get hit once they will hide behind a shield or a wall and dodge arrows.  They seem to remember you were shooting at them too.  The baddies don't have a huge aggro range and you can usually get prepared to face them.  I do like the inventory system in the game and don't have to worry so much about what I can and can't carry.  Just about everything in the game is interactable.  There is also loot everywhere.  It is rather enjoyable searching for loot in hard to reach places or finding something and figuring out how to get it.  I really enjoy this game and I hope this company will use this game engine to make more titles in the future.

What a great experience. One of the best games for the Vive so far, and the best VR RPG hands down. Can't wait for the next installments.

It's short, but not too short. You won't get through it in a single session, most likely it will take several, depending on your VR stamina.

Pros:

- Great use of the Vive with some interesting mechanics that play out really well, like throwing things to knock treasures off of high ledges, and the utility belt approach to inventory.

- Several weapon choices that offer different playstyles for each one, from the sword & board, to the bow, to the dragon wand (nuclear option), and a couple of others. This lends some replayability to the game that otherwise might not be there... I want to replay it just to master the 2-handed battle axe, which is probably the toughest weapon to master in the game. Not due to poor design, it just takes some practice to get right, and your first time through you'll probably gravitate to the easier weapons.

- Well-balanced gameplay. The difficulty seems appropriate at each level of the game, and it's never too easy or hard. By the time you hit the trials, you'll be swashbuckling and teleporting like it's second nature, but you'll still need to be fast on your feet while staying on top of your situational awareness to win.

- It's got some flavor. Just the simple act of lighting all the candles and torches you find is deeply satisfying (plus there's an achievement for it). There's some treasure that's pretty well hidden too, look absolutely everywhere. Burn stuff. Shoot apples.

- Combat is very fulfilling. Some of the enemies are downright tough, and order some replacement foam rings right now, because you're going to break a sweat. Sidestep to flank, teleport behind, low shot under the shield, duck and cover, come over the top with the battle axe... all valid tactics, and you're going to want to use them.

- No stability problems or gameplay issues. Smooth and easy.

- You haven't lived until you've dodged a fireball three inches from your face.

Not much in the way of Cons, but I'll try:

- It's linear. As mentioned before, the various weapons offer different playstyles for each, but essentially there is nothing procedural or random about the game. However, the overall experience is enough fun that I'll play it through a few more times anyway.

- ALMOST too short, but I'm going to give Indimo a hall-pass here because, relatively speaking, it's the most fulfilling RPG out there so far IMO. They have also laid the groundwork for some really playable (and replayable) mechanics that I hope to see more of in future releases.

- Some of the lore poetry is pretty hokey.

All in all, with the state of the art as it is, Vanishing Realms is an absolute must-buy, and hopefully soon turns into a franchise that I'll be sticking with for the duration.

Highly recommended 9.5/10.

26304507.review:
Nach den "äußerst positiven" Bewertungen habe ich mich für dieses Spiel entschieden. Leider wurde ich enttäuscht.

=======================
Warum ich das Spiel nicht mag:
=======================

(-) Die Kämpfe machen mir persönlich wenig Spaß. Grund: Die Künstliche Intelligenz der Gegner ist sehr schlicht. Selbst Bossgegner stehen immer wieder einfach da und können problemlos aus der Entfernung mit Pfeil und Bogen abgeschossen werden. In anderen Situationen (Nahkampf) funktionieren Kämpfe aber wie gewünscht und machen dann auch Spaß.

(-) Zur Fortbewegung muss man sich in kleinen Schritten durch sehr große Areale teleportieren. Problem: Ständiges Teleportieren ist suboptimal. Es bringt einen aus der Spielwelt, da der Kopf ab einer gewissen Häufigkeit die Umgebung als "nicht real" wahrnimmt. Wären die Areale anders gestaltet, würden sich die Teleports pro Zeiteinheit reduzieren. Andere Titel machen das besser. 

(-) Der Höhepunkt des Spiels ist eine kleine Arena. Diese muss man schätzungsweise acht mal durchlaufen, um das Spiel zu knacken. Das Schema ist dabei immer gleich. Beim 3. mal war ich der Arena leider bereits überdrüssig.

(-) Ich habe sehr langsam gespielt und komme auf eine Spielzeit von knapp 3 Stunden. Sehr wenig für 20€, zumal auch viel Leerlauf und Wiederholungen dazwischen sind (=>Arena).

(-) Das Inventar ist fummelig und dort platziert, wo in der echten Welt der Bauch wäre. Problem: Es ist immer am unteren Linsenrand --> Das Inventar ist grundsätzlich unscharf, da außerhalb des Sweet Spots. Das strengt die Augen an.

(-) Schwertkämpfe funktionieren auf zwei Arten: Man tut was das Spiel von einem will, oder man fuchtelt einfach wild und ohne Ziel rum. Leider funktioniert beides.

(-) Wenige Gegnertypen mit wenig "Charakter". Die einzige Sprachausgabe in diesem Spiel ist "hoooooh". Das geben Gegner von sich wenn sie zuschlagen.

(-) Es existiert leider keine nennenswerte Story abseits von englischen Texttafeln.

==================
Was am Spiel positiv ist:
==================

(+) Die Schwertkämpfe machen durchaus Spaß

(+) Bogenschießen annähernd wie bei "The Lab" umgesetzt.

(+) Man kann eine Spitzhacke finden, mit der man Kristalle, Edelsteine abbauen kann. Das macht so lange Spaß bis man merkt, dass es im ganzen Spiel vielleicht 10 Stellen gibt, wo man diese einsetzen kann.

(+) Mancher schöne Aha-Moment im Spiel für Leute mit noch wenig VR Erfahrung.

(+) Es ist ein VR Spiel

=====
Fazit:
=====

Ohne Virtual Reality wäre dieses Spiel wohl nicht relevant. Umfang gering, Grafikstil recht austauschbar, viele Designmacken. Virtual Reality macht daraus dann eine interessante Erfahrung, die aber ausbaubar ist. An anderer Stelle (Rec Room -> Mittelalter zB) hatte ich deutlich mehr Spaß für weniger Geld pro Spielzeit.

26288259.review:
Dies ist eine klare Empfehlung. Vanishing Realms ist das erste Vive-Spiel, das ich gespielt habe und das keine Tech-Demo ist oder nach 1h langweilig wird. Den Reviews auf Steam bei VR-Games traue ich schon lange nicht mehr. Alle scheinen immer sofort begeistert zu sein, aber haben meistens nicht mehr als 1h gespielt. Natürlich ist der erste Eindruck meistens wirklich bombastisch (ist halt VR), aber der Spielspaß läßt oft schnell nach. Das ist bei Vanishing Realms anders. Dazu komme ich später.

Erstmal die Spiele, die ich für Vive besitze und aus denen ich meine Erfahrung schöpfe:

Fantastic Contraption: Könnte für manche interessant sein, aber ich mag das Spielprinzip nicht. Puzzle sind nicht mein Ding.
Job Simulator: Macht ein paar Stunden Spaß, aber kein Wiederspielwert.
MIND Path to Thalamus: Wird schnell langweilig. Stundenlanges Rumgerenne ohne etwas tun zu müssen, aber schöne Welten.
Out of Ammo: Wave Shooter mit noch zuwenig Content, Spielspaß hält nicht lange an
Pool Nation VR: Leider eine Enttäuschung für mich. Miese Steuerung.
The Visitor: 5 Minuten Spielzeit
Zombie Training Simulator: Das ist wirklich gut und macht zwischendurch Spaß, aber leider immer das selbe und zuwenig Content. Trotzdem guter Wave-Shooter.
The Blue: Schönes Erlebnis, aber nur 10 Minuten Spielzeit

Vanishing Realms hatte ich zuerst nur relativ kurz angespielt, bin aber recht weit gekommen (hatte bereits den Bogen). Ich fand es nicht schlecht, aber auf Dauer eher lahm, bis ich mich vor wenigen Tagen intensiver mit dem Spiel beschäftigt habe und noch einmal von vorne angefangen habe.
Dabei ist mir aufgefallen, dass Vanishing Realms vor Secrets nur so wimmelt. Ziel sollte es sein, soviel Gold und Secrets zu finden, wie möglich. Nur dann bekommt man die beste Ausrüstung. Beim ersten Durchlauf konnte ich mir nur das schwächste Schwert und den schwächsten Bogen leisten und fragte mich, wie zur Hölle soll ich an soviel Gold kommen?
Jetzt habe ich festgestellt, dass unter dutzenden Steinen, Büchern, Kerzen,... Münzen versteckt sind. Außerdem kann man Vorhänge, Teppiche, Stroh, usw. mit der Fackel verbrennen und auch dahinter verbirgen sich Secrets. Man kann Kisten, Fässer, Vasen, Sargdeckel und alles mögliche zerschlagen. In den Räumen hängen in den Ecken Spinnweben mit Goldkrügen. Wenn man die Spinnweben verbrennt, fallen die Krüge in Reichweite. Es gibt geheime Orte. Dieser hier ist wirklich super: [spoiler]Auf der Insel, wo man eines der 3 Schwerter kaufen kann, ziemlich am Anfang, sollte man sich alle Inseln drumherum anschauen. Man findet u.a. einen roten wertvollen Krug (ingame Achievement) und auf einer entfernten Insel steht ein Grabstein mit einem Rätsel: Man soll ein Leuchtfeucher auf der Klippe entzünden. Es gibt eine Möglichkeit, dort hinzukommen und hinaufzukletter. Dabei findet man noch mehr Schätze auf dem Weg (Boot). Viel Spaß beim Suchen. [/spoiler]

Man kann und sollte also jeden Stein umdrehen und sich alles genau anschauen. Und bei der Länge des Spiels (es gibt viele Kapitel) ergibt sich daraus eine enorme Spielzeit. Außerdem gibt es ingame Achievements, die man unlocken kann, z.B. Entzünde 75 Kerzen, finde 30 rote Krüge, schiesse 20 Äpfel von Bäumen, etc. Auch das motiviert, alles mögliche zu versuchen. 
Ich habe jetzt mit dem Spiel neu angefangen und bereits wieder fast 2h am Stück gespielt und bin noch weit am Anfang (noch nicht mal da, wo ich beim ersten Mal Spielen nach nicht mal einer Stunde aufgehört habe), weil ich 100% erreichen will und ich habe dabei soviel neues entdeckt. Mein Tipp: Probiert alles aus, untersucht jeden Stein. Man kann z.B. mit Steinen oder Schädeln, usw. Goldkrüge von hochgelegenen Vorsprügen werfen, usw.

Nebenbei sind dann noch die Kämpfe mit Schwert/Schild und Bogen, die auch wirklich Spaß machen und auch da gibt es oft Möglichkeiten, Kämpfe zu umgehen oder starke Feine auf andere Art zu beseitigen. Die Physik im Spiel gefällt mir sehr gut, ebenso der Sound und die Sprachausgabe.

Ihr merkt, ich bin echt begeistert von dem Spiel und ich werde es definitiv weiter und durch spielen. Es ist für mich das ersrte "richtige" Spiel für die Vive und keine Techdemo ohne Langzeitmotivation. Ich hoffe, dass noch mehr dieser Spiele entwickelt werden.

Top Spiel. Bestes Vive-Spiel bisher. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

26271578.review:
What if one of the early Zelda games was a modern VR adventure? You've got your answer.

This is, by a long shot, one of the VR games you CANNOT miss.

It's also made by Kelly Bailey, the amazing musician behind the Half-Life soundtracks.

I also really want to praise the ambiance and atmosphere of the environments, which is REALLY good; in fact, if, like me, you're a Dota player, it feels like it could be a Dota spinoff, in some weird way... (and in fact, not only is the splash art by Jim Murray, but some of the 3D assets are, as far as I can tell, touched up Dota models)

Go for this, without hesitation. It's a great first (or second) step into VR.

26254538.review:
[A MAGICAL ADVENTURE ONLY SLIGHTLY SULLIED BY THE CLOSING CHAPTER]

This gives me that old, nostalgic feeling. Like playing the first Spyro game on the PS1 - except a hundred times cooler because it's a first person dungeon crawler in VR.

- The controls are very intuitive and natural feeling. I'll roll up to a table, toss all the candles over my shoulder, swipe up all the pennies hidden underneath, and chuck the apples in to my backpacks - and it all feels super smooth. 
- The inventory system works great. I can switch up my equipment on the fly really easily, even the stuff in the backpacks. It was occasionally hard to get in the right place, and I often found that I couldn't access it at all while crouching, but most of the time I didn't even have to think about it.
- Moving is done through teleportation, which is pretty standard for a lot of games. Works just fine for this :) Though I did find that it made dodging projectiles and traps super easy! 
- Some really cool events/encounters and interweaving level design (made me think of Dark Souls, coming back out in a familiar places etc).
- Difficulty curve was just right
- Pacing felt right on too - the first chapter didn't drag on but also didn't feel like it zoomed by!

Something that I really appreciate is that is the ability to play this game with a left handed loadout!
Sure, it automatically wants you to put your shield in your left hand and sword in the right, but who says you need to do that? Swap em over and beat those skellies senseless - southpaw style!


The only thing that I felt let me down was the second chapter.

Chapter 1 was wonderful, and I really felt a sense of accomplishment when I finished it. When I moved on to Chapter 2 I saw this cool environment and I was super stoked about the idea of exploring this sun-soaked, temple-looking place - anticipating further challenge with new enemies and maybe some gear upgrades! Building on the content I'd already experienced.
But then it ended up basically just being a series of arena "kill the dudes" challenges and nothing more. It felt more like the kind of thing you'd access from the main menu as a separate challenge mode mini-game. I certainly couldn't call it a chapter.

This does nothing to diminish the fun I had in C1, but I hope that the next instalments are more like that than C2. 

Had a whale of a time and this is still my favourite VR experience yet!
 I'm looking forward to seeing what further content is like ^^

26063752.review:
[i]Vanishing Realms[/i] is a VR dungeon crawler that sets out to give a glimpse of what is possible in this new genre.

And if you think hand-to-hand combat with undead creatures might be a bit exhausting, you'd be right. This is not a criticism of the game. As a broad first attempt to get swords, shields, bows and magical items into the hands of players who must use them to block, thrust, parry, dodge and aim while maintaining situational awareness, this game succeeds very well.

What VR demonstrates is that this type of action can be tiring and sweaty work. While it isn't [i]Dance Revolution[/i], having a mask strapped to your face while you are flailing around with toy-like 3D weaponry can result in a lots of facial moisture, foggy eyepieces (no ventilation) and tired arms to accompany the silly grin on your face. Fortunately there's an in-game pause button that allows you to take off your headset, wipe your brow and reach for the adventurer's mead (aka Gatorade). [i]Also it's far more deadly to learn a good stance and sweeping motions instead of trying to bat enemies with wrist flicks. You're using a sword, not a fly-swatter![/i]

Given that this is first-gen VR, this game can also be forgiven for it's cartoon-like world. We're likely some ways off from having Skyrim-esque settings in VR, but if you play this and imagine that one day you might be able to fight Draugr underneath some forgotten cairn in the middle of a snowy pine forest, then it's worth noting this game helped get us there.

Story? Meh. You have no real identity in this game and there is no world to discover, just a series of locations and quest objectives. There's a few easy puzzles to figure out. And for the final act you get to do several rounds of timed arena combat (the Rite of Steel).

I recommend this game with reservations. It's clearly one of the front-runners of the current pack of Vive games that attempt to be more than a demo, yet it still feels demo-like: short, no story and focused on introductory mechanics. One chapter is currently available with another promised to complete the game and a possible third as DLC. That might give it enough length to justify the full price if it happens in the near future. The game won't keep this front-runner position for long as other, newer titles inevitably push beyond those boundaries.

[b]Rating: 7/10
A good intro to first-gen VR gaming, but lacking a fully fleshed-out experience.[/b]

25830230.review:
Just got the Vive set up over the weekend, so I'm as new as they come with VR.  Maybe it's because I'm only a few hours into my VR journey and the novelty has not worn off yet, but this game kinda blew my mind. It's a bit simplistic... this is true... but this experience has changed the way I feel about gaming forever.  Like I said... this is one of my very first VR experiences, so perhaps if I wrote this in the future after spending a couple hundred hours in VR experiences, I'd not write so enthusiastically about this... but for now, I love this game.

I'll try to be objective though to hopefully help someone make a decison about whether or not to buy this.   The setting is kinda cartoony and the enemies look a little Zelda-ish, but when engaged in a sword fight with enemies slightly larger then me, the innocence of their looks temporarily fades away and they feel a bit more menacing.  And that cartoony setting has a real sense of scale and of being a real place.   From the slight vertigo I feel looking over an edge to the floor below me, to feeling moon beams soaking into my skin... It all comes together quite nicely. 

The only criticisms I have are that melee combat is a little easy and repetetive.  Block, strike, block strike... it's hard to mess up. Regardless, it's still fun.   And there are other combat options such as a ranged bow which are fun to use.

Another minor gripe is that enemies seems to just stand around and wait for you to approach.  Would be much cooler if they were a bit more aggressive and plentiful.  But then again, for a VR noob like me, maybe it would be a little too fast paced. 

My biggest overall complaint is that I want more. 

But, none of these things stopped me from having one of the best times in recent memory.  I can't wait to see more games of this type!  Bravo! Well done!

So, if you are new to VR like I am and the VR experience is still fresh, I think it's worth the money to try this one. I don't think you'll be disappointed!

25828650.review: This game is fantastic!  Still in its youth, but the best form of a live-ish action RPG that I've played yet.  There is no concept of leveling, or skills, you just have gold that you find and you buy weapons with it.  Mana doesn't replenish, but you can increase your stock.  I had a blast with this and the first chapter definitely had a lot more content.  I'd love to see this game go a bit farther to give people some good feel as to what VR RPGs might start off as, but then I'd like somebody to get this guy a team and some cash flow becuase this has the right feel to it.  I felt like a kid with a tonka toy mining stuff and crawling under traps was a lot of fun.  If there was a multiplayer concept this could slowly make itself into a Runescape-esque early game for the VR that paves the way and gets interest started for this type of game.  Buy this game.

Bottom line: As far as HTC Vive games go, I have mixed feelings about this game. I like it because it's a high-fantasy dungeon crawler. 

I managed to complete the first level. The combat was interesting enough, and I like the fact that I got to try out some melee fighting, bow shooting, and magic via magic wand. 

I found the pacing to be... odd. For example, the first level often felt slow because of the exploration component. At least walking around was punctuated with combat encounters. The 2nd level had a completely different pacing. Little or no exploration, but it becomes frantic because activities are timed. I have a particular annoyance for timed things, and I eventually lost interest and stopped playing this game when I kept failing the time-based challenge. For whatever reason, there just isn't enough payoff in other ways for me to bring the same level of enthusiasm for meeting this video game challenge. I enjoyed Dark Souls 1. I am enjoying my first playthrough of Doom2016 in Nightmare difficulty. I'm not really inspired to meet the challenge in this game, for whatever reason.

Though I've only gotten 2.6 hrs in this game, it is by far the best title I've played on the Vive. 

Game play is absolutely phenomenal. I thought that I'd be turned off by the teleportation movement (which caused me to hesitate adding this title to my library) but to my suprize it works just fine with it and doesn't seem to break immersion.

Sword play is perfect - better than any other title to date. The bow isn't great but is not bad either. I wish the dev would work more on this mechanic and allow arrows to be drawn and nocked similar to 'QuiVR'. It's awesome to see arrows blocked by the shield poking through the other side. 

Interactions with objects is completely satisfying - from mining ore to breaking containers and glass to lighting curtains, pillows, banners, leaves and spider webs on fire. 


Graphics are top notch for a VR title and everything is absolutely wonderous. The world feels alive and is very interactive. 

The haptics feel dead on and the controls are smooth. Even the auto-pause feature (which irritated me at the beginning) is a nice addition to keep you within the chaperone area and from breaking your controllers. You can turn this off, but I left it on since it didn't seem to break the immersion too much.

I look forward to playing this for several more hours and will be buying the 3rd chapter.

If you've been holding off on this title for reasons of movement or any other reason - just buy it already. I wish I had gotten it sooner.

I love this game. It takes me right back to the 90's style 'forgotten realms' style games, especially with the use of teleportation. 
The combat is fairly simple although I enjoy parrying the attacks with my sword and countering. The graphics are high quality and most things in the game are interactive, just make sure you are not standing next to some hay if you are setting it alight or you will soon die. The gameplay is also fun - I found myself crawling under the swinging sytthes to get passed.

There are a few niggles within the game that I hope the developers will sort out/fix:
The hands are currently orbs rather than actual hands, which is a bit of a let down for a dungeon rpg style game.
Also it would be nice if there could be a controller walk/strafe control option as well as the teleportation.

Overall an excellent game and I can't wait for the full polished game to be released.

25629941.review:
I do not recommend this game in a vaccum. Read on before marking as "not helpful" - it's not Reddit, this is a thought-out user review, not an epic troll on an internet forum.

TL;DR - The game is actually somewhat polished, which automatically puts it head and shoulders above 99% of the SteamVR lineup. However, a slew of disappointing design flaws and the cheese-ability of the combat system do little to justify the pricetag when the game is as short as it is. If you're not too picky and willing to play along, go for it.

Pros & cons:

Pros
-quality artstyle, decent enough ambiance to create significant immersion
-the linear levels work without feeling railroady
-sound effects and "game feel" work in VR, picking up coins and striking enemies doesn't feel like a chore
-VR allows exploration to feel more like exploration, and less like a slog
-A few nice and simple environmental puzzles keep the game from being a complete wagglefest.

Cons
-Combat is incredibly easy to cheese. Waggling your sword at an enemy's head essentially guarantees victory. Add in a few quick teleports from place to place on bosses, and you've got a low-effort strategy that can wreck anything without actually playing along.
-No artificial locomotion options. Unless it was some hidden options menu I missed, there was no way of giving the player any option other than teleportation. While TP is a nice default for comfort's sake, there are people who would like to use it, especially in the early days of roomscale VR software.
-It's short as all hell.
-It's insultingly easy, even if you play along and don't cheese fights. The telegraphs are massive, and the shield blocks EVERYTHING with no penalties.
-Melee enemies pretend you don't exist until you're already in striking distance. I was expecting to be ganged up on numerous times by the enemy configurations, and never was unless I explicitly tried to. Even when I was firing the bow+arrow at their friends, they never did anything but look confusedly in my direction sometimes. 
-Exploration yields little, save for a few coins. 

ALL THIS BEING SAID, Vanishing Realms is still one of the best VR games I've played. For most, the novelty of VR outweighs the subpar nature of the game itself. And that's fine, but I still wouldn't recommend this game on its own.

Fantastic game where you actually swordfight giant skeletons, explore mazes, cast magic spells, wield a bow and arrow, mine gold, disarm traps, find treasure, solve puzzles.

It's Dungeons and Dragons, but you get to go into the game.  You aren't rolling dice, you are really swinging a sword, holding a shield, ducking behind rocks to avoid flying arrows.

Not pushing a button so some little guy on screen swings a sword.  Not waggling a controller.  Really swordfighting.  It's amazing.

Think the skeletons look like a cartoon on the video?  Wait till you're fighting one in VR.  They're scary enough!  Unless you are playing this in VR you cannot have the slightest idea how real it actually feels.

One of a handful of games worth getting a VR system for.  This is the real deal.

I can't wait until there are more levels.

My background: Not a gamer really, have tried and tried, but the only games I truly have enjoyed is Age of Empires 1 & 2, Diablo 1- 3, Silver and Portal 2. I dont like sitting still while playing. So I bought a Vive, and i own 70 titles at this point. Or more. I can´t get enough.

Vanishing realms: This is, without a doubt the best game I have ever played. Yes, there are some things that need to be fixed, and it is still early access. But it is truly astounding he amount of joy I get running through this wonderful Dungeon Crawler! This is the game i dreamt about as a child! Thank you Devs, you are true heroes!


I play on warrior mode, got to sixth rite of passage where I got tangled in my cable and yanked the power cable out of my link box ^^:

Good Stuff:
Swordplay: Amazing! I will not say it cant improve, but holy hell! you guys really put in alot of work compared to any other game I have ever seen. Keep it up!

Ai: Sure, there are still some dumb stuff the monsters do, but the AI in this is sometimes scary good.
Big plus for the trap devs! Got me seriously fooled!

Bow and arrow: Excellent. Just leave it as it is. Maby make it more real and harder still. But if not, its fine as it is!

Gameplay and movement: I enjoy the heck out of it! I don´t mind the teleportation too much, even though it always sucks, your teleportation is the least suckiest at the moment. The game kind of makes up for it in this case :) The story is a little bit thin, but it feels like the devs are working up to something. I can´t wait! I almost got tears in my eyes when i found the new path!

The riddles: They are wonderfully written :)

Bad stuff:
I dropped both my pick-axes accidentally, and both disappeared into the floor or wall or somewhere. Could not find them again. So I had to play a very long way around before I got it all back to where I wanted to be. It´s ok though, it was fun ;) Still, if i drop something, I want to be able to pick it up.

Got some bugs where I suddenly, after teleporting, was standing right in front of a monster that had not been there before. Scared the living smurfs out of me. Only happened once.


Some words to the devs:
Do not make it easier. Do not let people tell you they have to be able to pick through inventory faster or anything like that. Remember, this is VR, make it as you are doing now. So that we have to get physically better irl to get better in the game. Thats the beauty of vr! Don´t you think?

Thank you devs! You are wonderful and I love your game.

25427271.review:
[b][i]Vanishing Realms[/i] is an outstanding full-on RPG experience built for VR.[/b] While a vast majority of VR games (at this point) are tech demos, this title really brings the content. And it is done well. Updates are continuous, and things have changed dramatically through the time that I have owned it. 

[i]Essentially, this is a classic RPG with all the regular bells-and-whistles you would expect, only it is for VR![/i] You collect loot, buy stuff at shops, dungeon crawl, buy better equipment, use magic, carry torches, and solve riddles!

[i]Vanishing Realms[/i] excels at being immersive in VR. The dark dungeons and [i]hugggeee[/i] creatures really are impressive, and at times scary, in VR.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Definatley has meat-on-the bone as far as VR games goes (so many right now are short proof-of-concept or tech demo-ish kinds of deals)
+Very immersive experience
+Constant developement
+Combat is really well done, and definately tactical
+Solid VR control scheme

[b]Cons:[/b]
-I would say this is expensive if it were not a VR game, but thats the VR market

[b]If you have VR and want a solid RPG right now, this should be in your library.[/b]

25392360.review:
Vanishing Realms sets the bar for room scale VR.  At first go 'round, the length of the overall quest seems short; however, two major updates have brought refinement and replayability.  Even if this was a game you would only play once, it's a must-have for your VR library.  The immersion, game mechanics, atmosphere, and attention to detail are unparalleled to any other game out there.

If you wish to show-off the full potential of room scale VR, this is the game you'd demo to your friends and family.

If you ever dreamed of crawling a dungeon for fame and fortune, Vanishing Realms lets you live out those dreams.

I look forward to the near future when we can all go online into a massive VR world with parties of wizards, dwarves, and clerics to slay the unholy beasts that terrorize our lands.  As amazing as Vanishing Realms is, it is a glimmer in the eye of what VR will be.  That said, it is the most clear and  insightful glimmer you can buy today.

25371418.review:
This is what VR is all about. Most other games for VR are just rehashing of existing game play while only a few give you a true sense of being "in" the game. If more developers would follow this style, VR will go a long way. If developers keep giving us seated experiences that make people sick and aren't much better in VR than playing on a monitor, VR will be just another fad that will fade. More games for VR should be like this one. Absolutely amazing job they have done on this game and I can't wait for the future as they learn from this game.

One frustration is the save game location. When you die, it appears to take you two saves back instead of the last save point. This means having to redo steps, puzzles, etc. over again that you have already done between the last save point and the previous save point.

And two handed axe is worthless in my opinion. It is harder than a sword and shield, so don't see the use when you get killed faster and don't do any additional damage versus the sword and shield.

25185518.review:
[b]A great proof of concept so far.[/b]

While it's certainly rough around the edges so far and the second part is little more than an arena, it's great to see how well a sword & sorcery type of adventure works on the Vive.

You move around teleporting and you have your two controllers as hands to which you can equip various things. There's no limb severing or anything like that, but the sword fighting was especially satisfying. The main trick is to block and punish. Blocking can be done both with a shield and a sword. Arrow/ranged combat isn't as refined as in other games like the Lab or Trickster, but it serves its purpose well enough. Plus Vanishing Realms is more of an actual game than either of those two as it stands already.

I hope future versions will get a bit more finesse and depth to the combat, enemies other than just skeletons, and that the future maps will be more akin to the first one rather than the second. As far as VR games go though, this is well worth the price compared to a lot of the other non-free VR "games" out there on Steam.

This is the first high-caliber RPG / fighting game for the Vive, and it's fantastic. Highly polished, scarily convincing in some moments, but accessible even to non-gamer sorts. For the devs - I'd enjoy replaying this game for easily 3x as long if some features like the following were added:
