23125260.review:
I have just started playing through Vanishing Realms for the second time, this time I am recording my adventure and thoughts as I go along https://youtu.be/hL1XfwmHstE

It is kind of true that the game is short, and I am still sort of confused as to how future content is going to be pushed through (ie as free updates or as new paid for episodes). However, since VR is new and has limited users its completely understandable why games such as this, which have a cost associated with them only last two to three hours. The developers have to price their games in a way that will bring them a return when sales will be lower than the general PC market. Got it.

That said, the couple of hourse of gameplay that are available with Vanishing Realms are a heck of a lot of fun. I often felt like I was playing the role Indiana Jones and the environments are absoluetly stunning in VR.

However, it is the room scale that really pushes the bar high. Being able to stroll around your own little space, lighting torches, peering over edges and looking through windows provides a gaming experience that I have simply never come close to having before. That isn't to say it is the best gaming I have ever had, it isn't; but it is so radically different to everything I have done before that comparing Vanishing Realms to any stadard monitor driven game would be like comparing apples and oranges. 

So, Vanishing Realms is short but awesomely entertaining.

The combat is also very done. I generally don't emjoy first person combat games. Call of Duty? No thanks, not for me. However, even though this is technically a first person RPG, I wouldn't have it any other way. If this is a taste of things to come, then I can safely say that the first person gaming was simply made for VR... it just started out a few years before the tech :) Having a skeleton stand right in front of you hammering his rusty blade in your face can be genuinely intimidating. However, being able to lift your own sword (not a mouse/keyboard but an actual physical object in your hand that is perfectly tracked) in order to parry those attacks and then being able to thrust it into it's head to deplete its health is incredibly satisfying.

Sadly, there is a slight negative because things turn a little bit less satisfying once you have equipped the bow and arrow. You see, the AI is not particularly good, and as long as you stay at a distance you can spam your arrows to kill the enemies and they won't even move towards you. They can strafe a little from time to time but as soon as I had the bow all the danger became almost completely inert and that was a real shame. In the end I just put the bow away and only used it when absolutely necessary, ie if enemies could not be reached via melee, but it seems like a silly thing to have to do to get the most enjoyment out of the game.

That said, I highly recommend Vanishing Realms to anybody who has a Vive. Feel free to watch my video (linked at the start of my review) for a general idea of what the game is about, but this won't even begin to give you a taster of the actual experience. The game is great, so I thank the developer for their efforts and I can't wait to see what will be coming next!

Fuzz

23125232.review: One of the best, if not the best VR games I've ever played (including Oculus titles). 23123117.review:
10/10 The best gaming experience I have ever had, on any platform. Ever.

Let me start by saying, this is an early access game, which should make what I will say all the more impactful. Also, to set the context, I am in my mid 40's and remember playing Pong, getting an Atari 2600 in 1977 (coinciding with Star Wars, what a great year), owning Intellivision 1 and 2, Colecovision, NES, IBM PC jr, Commodore 64, XBOXes, PS's, you name it. I like games. I am an avid board gamer, I have designed games and was my groups Dungeon Master in D&D going back to 1980. In terms of VR, I backed DK1, bought a DK2, and own an Oculus CV1 and the HTC Vive. I've played every TES game, All of the Ultimas (started with Ultima 2 when it came out.)

This is some next nevel shit....and by that I mean thanks to VR.  skipping some levels that should have somehow been in there in between. All credit to Palmer Lucky and other innovaters for what we are now able to experience. 

Now, some things to get out of the way about this game right now. Be warned, that unless you are someone who enjoys early access to games, this is not for you. I feel this warning should be READ before people buy these titles. It's right there in blue, but people seem to ignore it.

The game is too short at this time. The game does not have realistic monsters, or AAA title graphics. You MUST make sure to set up your Vive perfectly to get the most out of this, and by that I mean make sure your play area is well defined with a good amount of room. Mine is 2m x 2m and my gut tells me that is minimum to REALLY enjoy this game once you start swinging around your weapon. Make sure your hardware supports smooth frame rates with the Vive.

Once all of the finicky parts are set, you can launch into the game. I will say this again, but I don't like the look of the monsters- but I believe most younger gamers will prefer it. I like more "serious" looking monsters, just a preference. While you are walking around in the world and interacting with it, this won't matter at all. In the heat of combat, I found it almost startling how something that looks pretty standard on the monitor, can be intimidating once you are fitted into it's scaled den. I love the inventory system, where you only need to look down at your belt and pouches and grab what you need. Eat food to improve health, grab a sword in one hand and a shield in the other, or a staff, or a bow. The immersion factor is top notch. The weapons feel great. Ducking and side stepping ranged attacks feels phenomenal.

I will give you one example in the game to show you why this is the greatest gaming experience I have ever had.

Deep in the heart of a battle with 3 orcs and 2 floating magic users hurling magic fireballs at me, I hurried to a cluster of rocks. I crouched behind the rocks and watched as fireballs just missed me and singed the side of the rocks I was leaning against. I decided to try to pick off the high floating magic users first. I noted that each time I would attack the orcs, these damned MU's would heal them. I grabbed my trusty bow. I waited until a blast hurled past me. I leaned out just enough to see the enemies and focused on the one closest to me. I slowly drew back my arrow, and tried to aim just above the MU, keeping steady. I released the arrow and made a hit. I continued to pound him and when I got him low in HP, he began to heal himself. I knew I had to increase the rate of my hits. I found a better spot to attack him. A barrage of hits met their mark, and I took the first MU down. I used this tactic to take out the other MU, and had to sidestep his balls of fire while making my way to a tree that was good cover, but closer in range to him. Once I dispatched him, I put away my bow and healed up a bit as quickly as I could. I then drew my sword in my right hand, and my shield in the left. I rushed the orcs, and in a fit of slashes I dealt damage to them. I would use the shield to try to block attacks from one, while stabbing and slashing the others. I finally killed them all and took their treasure. I then made my way into a cave opening I spotted, stopping only to catch my breath.

Cons-
Short gameplay (at this point in early access)
Very small number of enemies
Combat can be a little easy (would be great if difficult levels could be added, increasing number, strength, and type of monsters)
Graphics -Not even so much the level of graphics, I prefer a more serious "look" to the monsters, similar to TES or old school D&D. However, I really don't care that much that it should detract from my rating. The environments look great.

Pros-
Immersive beyond anything else I have ever done
Pace is good
Just enough story to keep things moving (some more voice acting could be added but not a negative at all)
Inventory system
Weapons, while low in variety, feel great
Atmosphere, good visuals for VR and ambient sound

Summary - Even at this early stage, the greatest gaming experience I have ever had in terms of immersion and feeling as though I was IN a dungeon or ON a mountain etc. Once complete, with added length, variety and difficulty scaling, it will likely be the best entertainment experience (for me) in almost 40 years when I got into Star Wars.

23120235.review:
When I purchased an HTC Vive, my intent was to play flight sims and space sims and the like. I assumed, wrongly, that full body VR would be poorly implemented, and that a game like Vanishing Realms would be dull and uninteresting. I'm not going to mislead anyone here and say the story is particularly original, but if you have a VR setup, you CAN NOT AFFORD NOT TO PLAY THIS GAME!
Vanishing Realms absolutely pulled me into a fantasy realm, and made me forget I was a grown man, flailing his arms around with a big buggy looking mask on his face. For a time, I was an adventurer, slowly moving through a dark hall, torch held over my head in one hand, longsword shaking in the other. 
The current chapter of the game will run you two hours of playtime if you take the time to search for treasure and enjoy the story. I am eagerly awaiting the next installment. 
Last thought: if you're not sure whether this game is for you, think back to when you were a kid, swinging a ruler around at imaginary monsters; deep down, you're still that kid, and this game perfectly places you into your younger selfs imaginary battle.

23108106.review:
The game is a crude dungeon crawler, just as it promises. Age-old actions like smashing crates, picking up every little coin, and solving simple puzzles are surprisingly compelling when you're in VR. I recommend it. If you've already bought a Vive, then $20 is not bad for the only game that can currently provide hours of full-body VR content and that is very solid compared to the other VR games available to day.

The motion and navigation controls are good. I could play over an hour without motion sickness. I really like that the game prevents you from sticking your head through walls or warping to distant locations...it genuinely feels like you're walking through a dungeon.

It is unfortunate that sword fighting feels like a Wii game instead of real sword fighting, but that's not the developer's fault--swinging a motion control just doesn't have the inertia to inspire realistic motions and you end up just waggling the sword.

The interface for changing weapons and for accessing the inventory needs a bit more design. When you're crouched, you can't access your inventory (I think it goes under the ground due to 3D clipping), and you have to remember to grab the bow with your off hand instead of the one that you'll shoot with. It would be better if weapons were mounted at different points on your body, so that you could really draw a sword or unsling the bow from your back instead of pushing buttons to have them magically appear.

23076293.review:
A M A Z I N G !

Seriously this is why I bought VR. I had a grin from ear to ear the entire time I was playing this game. If you play this game the way it was meant to be played you will have an absolute blast!. You can of course try to cheat (saw a few videos of people exploiting) but if that's what you are going to do.. why did you buy VR?

I love the combat and with a couple wrist weights on my arm it turned into a realistic workout. I hope more content comes out and a few more monsters. I love what is in the game right now, I was ducking and weaving, the more space you can give this game the better it will play. That being said I was playing just under the 2m X 2m space but I was able to make due just fine, I just wish I had a bit more space.

If you are running room scale VR and always wanted to battle the undead with swords and shields or a bow and arrow then buy this game, seriously, do not hesitate. It may be a bit cartoony but it gets the job done. This is a dungeon crawl that seriously made me glad I bought the Vive over the competition.

Why are you still reading this? Adventures await! This game is worth it at double the price!

Edit - 

I have now used the Oculus Rift and room scale with this game as well as the HTC Vive. I would like to comment on how the game handles with the Rift. The Rift plays quite well with 3 sensor room scale. I did not have any issues at all. I was able to set up the Rift sensors to get good tracking even when on the ground, at times I felt I had better control on the ground with the Rift vs Vive. At no time did I feel any disconnect in the hour I played. I was quite pleased! I then attempted to use the game with only 2 sensors. I would highly not recommend this. This game requires full 360 tracking and 2 sensors will not give you 100%, I was able to get it to a playable level but I did run into disconnect issues with the controllers and it breaks the flow of the game.

If you have 3 sensor room scale for the Oculus Rift this game is a must have!!!!!

23075698.review:
Classic-style dungeon-crawler done VR-style.  Destroy all who stand before you and take their valuables.  Block the skeleton's attacks and counter while their guard is down, dodge the skele-archer's arrows while you close into melee range, or, in the alternative, take cover and pop in/out while peppering them with arrows.  And if you value your life, GTFO of the way of the big skeleton bosses' downward strikes.

AI could use an aggression boost, and the puzzles are a bit simple. Nevertheless, its quite an enjoyable title, and should be fun for the whole family.

23061787.review:
This is a long time wet dream of mine. This is what I've always wanted from VR. To be the hero. Be in the fantasy world. Swing the sword at monsters, and parry their blows. 

Sure, the game is far from perfect. It's developed by a single person, and while it's amazing what he's achieved, I see that as a con. That's because the game can never be as deep or polished as if if came from a big studio with loads of programming resources. This isn't Skyrim VR, and it probably never will be. 

But, IMHO, the #1 reason why every Vive owner should buy this game is to send a message to those big studios. When Bethesda & co look at Steam sales reports, they should see clear evidence that there is a huge craving for this sort of game.

23056129.review:
First off, I wanted to say Thank You to the dev/s of this game! You gave this game some love and it shows!
In simple terms; this game is fun!  It's a bit short, but I'm hoping for more content in the future.
It's the little things that stand out for me in this game. They make you feel as if you are actually holding a shield and a sword (or bow and arrow, etc). It really stands out when you compare it to some others like it; yes, you can just wave your sword around, but you can also actually use it!  On the last level, I was getting really good at going around their shields (or under or over) to kill in very few strokes.  The map accuracy for the bows and arrows were surprisingly accurate, allowing for hiding behind cover, aiming without looking (stretch the arms around the corner), dodging incoming arrows, and, for the slow, looking down at the arrows sticking out of you!  LOL, AND they move faithfully when you do, persisting long enough to be disconcerting!
I have now been spoiled; games that don't allow me to clash my sword on my shield really suck!  
The maps were also imaginative and fun, keeping you thinking and on your toes!  
I LOVED the inventory management in this one!  I had a bit of a problem with losing items in between saves, but nothing that mattered (which is probably why they disappeared).  Seriously, the inventory system is worth experiencing all by itself!

I definitely recommend this one and hope for more!

23032943.review: This game isnt bad but like many VR experiences on the store there isn't much meat on its bones. With vanishing realms we are given a very short taste of what a virtual first person RPG could be like. You will explore, collect loot, unlock doors and fight monsters and that's pretty much it. I completed all the content available in about 100 minutes and by the end of it I would say that yes I had a good time. If you are desperate to play something on your new VR headset you can do worse than this game but be warned this title has more in common with an amusement park ride than an epic RPG. Chances are if you had enough money to buy a VR headset then the 19.99 asking price isnt outside your realm of affordability just don't go in expecting allot of bang for your buck.

23031818.review: Well, damn. This is way better than I was expecting, particularly for Early Access. Solid engagement, interesting mechanics, and some fun surprises. AI is a bit derpy, but feasible. Plays ok as a lefty.

23031761.review:
This is one of my favorite VR games so far. I really hope we see more games like this in the future! 

Pros:
-I am a big fan of the item belt and really didn't have any issues with inventory management. I used the simple tactic of putting useful items like the pick and torch in my left pouch and put food and potions in the right pouch and it works like a charm.
-Love the feel and atmosphere of the game world, I spent a few minutes in each area just looking around. You really feel like you are in a dank dungeon or mine. 
-Combat is fun and a little channenging at times (especially against two or more foes). The hit detection could use a little work, but I imagine that its hard to get a virtual sword with 1:1 motion controls to work and feel right. After all the sword and the skelleton you are swinging at are not really there. Over all I was impressed with how fun the combat is. 
-The puzzles, while not hard, required some thought.
-Felt very much immersed in the game. This is one of those games you say "Oh, Ill boot that up and play for 15 min." and then end up pulling the headset off an hour later saying "Wow! that was fun!"
-Felt like I was getting just a taster of what games will be like in a few years time. After my first hour in the game, I put it down and though "I really hope we see a major AAA game in this style." 
- Enemies feel intimidating and do protect themsevles well. They attempt to block or dodge arrows, and will cover up or step back if they are taking a beating. Also, watching my wife dancing across the room in an all out  fencing duel with thin air is always fun.
- Mini bosses and bosses were very fun and, I think, a great addition to the game. There are 6 types of enemies and each feel different and have different fighting styles/tactics. I found that killing them in the order of [spoiler] Healer -> Ranged -> melee [/spoiler] helped a lot, and was required in some fights. 

Cons:
- While satisfied with the game at the $20 asking price, I want more! I had a lot of fun playing this, and cant wait for the devs to make a sequel or similar. (beat the game in about 2 hours) 
- Sometimes when looking down at the inventory belt the HMD will slide up your face a tiny bit and make what you are trying to see blur. Not a huge problem and may not be an issue for people who can get their Vive securely glued to thier face. But with my giant head, I found myself reaching up and holding the Vive in place so I could see a few times.
- Because you are swinging the controllers around and moving quite a bit to dodge fireballs and arrows the game tries to keep you in the center of the play area so you dont hit something. This causes the game to pause with a screen that tells you to return to the center of the room and press pause to resume. While a fantastic idea so I dont break things, it does cut into the immersion a bit, sometimes popping up in the middle of a fight. a larger play area would probably help this a lot. (my play area is 2.2x2.1m)

23031334.review:
What a wonderful game and experience. 

As a fan of RPG's (and I've played ALOT) this is a great pioneer in the realm of VR. This is NO DOUBT a peak into the future of video games and what is to come.  

This game (along with a Vive) gives you the chance to experience playing an RPG like never before. In real life you can dodge arrows, spells, or the swing of an enemy sword. Use your shield or just step to the side in real life within your play area. Being able to duck and dodge by real body movements provides an amazing immersion experience. But do yourself a favor and be sure to use headphones and not speakers, helps a TON with the immersion. 

I highly recommend this game if you have a Vive, worth every penny.

23027095.review:
The game is short. My run took about 100 minutes. But it is nicely wrapped up in a package that feels complete story-wise (not that there is much of story).

But if you have a Vive, this title is well worth it as there is nothing else like it.

It is quite fun to beat up skeletons in swordfights. One thing that could have made it better would be if the AI was a bit better. Right now the enemies just stand there even if you are fighting one of their buddies literally 2 m away. It would be ok if they would pull from a larger radius so you would get a couple more fights where you face more than one at a time.
Also, the bow. The bow right now is sort of overpowered due to infinite arrows, and enemies at a distance will most of the time just stand there while you shoot at them over and over until they die - even if there is a fairly obvious path to you, and even if it's a "boss". Perhaps making arrows a limited resource would help. E.g. you could loot some arrows from the arrow-filled skeletons you find, and the bowmen you kill. On the other hand that means there should be some other way to kill bowmen on unreachable ledges (orberhaps you will be forced to just dodge them).

I remember as a kid, back in 1982 when The Warlock of Firetop Mountain book (Steve Jackson, Ian Livingstone - legends) came out.
Armed with pencil and paper and my trusty 2D6 (thats 2 six sided dice for the uninitiated), I was instantly transported into a dungeon which was populated with monsters, traps and puzzles.
It was mind blowing.
It was groundbreaking.
Vanishing Realms is the WOFTM of the VR age.
In five years time, we'll look back in fondness for this game as we play Skyrim VR.
-- if I had a gripe, it would be about not having enough traps :)
That's why you keep a halfling on the end of a 10 feet pole (old D&D joke).

22998113.review: One of the best VR games available now. It's very short and pricey but the experience shouldn't be missed.

22996017.review:
[H1]Vorab Information[/H1]

Fast ein Jahr ist vergangen seitdem ich mein Review hier geschrieben habe. Jetzt möchte ich es auffrischen:

Vanishing Realms ist sicherlich ein sehr gutes VR RPG (wobei die allgemeine Liste der VR RPGs recht klein ist) aber dennoch hat dass Spiel auch ein paar Macken, später mehr dazu.

Ich brauchte knapp 2.5 Stunden um das gesamte Spiel durch zu spielen (dabei habe ich sehr langsam gespielt und mir jede Ecke des Games genauer angeschaut). Das SPIEL (keine Erfahrung!) ist im allgemeinen das Geld wert aber nachdem die Storykomponente einmal beendet wurde gibt es keinen Wiederspielwert denn alle Items wurden bereits erbeutet und ich logge mich nicht nochmal ein nur weil ich einen Erfolg haben möchte, den ich bekomme wenn ich 50 Kerzen angezündet habe.



[H1]Negativ[/H1]

- Kein Wiederspieltwert! Du wirst das Spiel vermutlich nicht nochmal starten nachdem du die Story abgeschlossen hast. Es wäre sehr schön gewesen wenn sich der Developer ein System hätte einfallen lassen, dass den Spieler auch nach Beendigung der Story weiterhin beschäftigt.

- Es gibt lediglich eine einzige Möglichkeit sich Fortzubewegen (Teleport). Gerade in Kampfsituation hätte ich mir gewünscht nicht erst nach einem Platz zum teleportieren suchen zu müssen.

- Das ständige Bücken (wenn man so wie ich jedes Goldstück aufheben will) ist wirklich nicht sehr freundlich. Der Loot sollte immer in Spielerhöhe leicht zu greifen sein.

- Das Userinterface ist so lala, es funktioniert zwar, wird aber zum Ende des Spieles unglaublich unübersichtlich und überfüllt sich. So greift man schließlich anstatt zum Schwert dann doch zum Bogen oder Zauberstab.

- Monster droppen nur Gold/Mana. Ich hätte mir sehr gewünscht das Monster (gerade die Stärkeren) auch Ausrüstung droppen (so wäre eine wirklich Klassische RPG Komponente abgedeckt).

- Kein Aufleveln.

- Die Story wird nur auf Englisch (kein leicht verständliches Englisch) und über In-Game Texte erzählt.

- Gelegentliche Bildfehler beim Teleportieren (vor allem wenn man sich draußen Aufhält).

- Relativ niedrig aufgelöste Texturen (Der Stil ist trotzdem stimmig aber es könnte deutlich besser sein). Ich vermute das an sehr vielen Stellen Assets gekauft und benutzt wurden (völlig i.O und verständlich).



[H1]Positiv[/H1]

- Die Story lässt sich ganz gut spielen aber geht definitiv unter wegen dem herausragendem Kampfsystem

- Die allgemeine Stimmung im Spiel wird sehr gut umgesetzt. Man hat immer das Gefühl von einer "höheren Macht" beobachtet zu werden.

- Stimmige Soundeffekte mit Hall etc.

- Man kann mit sehr vielen Objekten interagieren, so lassen sich zum Beispiel Fässer zerstören und Heuhaufen und Banner in Brand setzen.

- Überall sind kleine Pokale versteckt die man sich erbeuten kann. Im Grunde wird man für alles was man in Brand setzt oder zerstört belohnt.



[H1]Fazit[/H1]

Ich empfehle jedem Spieler der sich für RPGs interessiert Vanishing Realms auszuprobieren. Das Geld ist das Spiel defintiv wert und vor kurzem gab der Developer bekannt, dass er nun an der dritten Erweiterung arbeitet. Wer dauerhaften Spaß sucht sollte erst noch abwarten um zu sehen ob der Entwickler daran arbeitet einen Wiederspielwert in das Spiel einzubauen.

Alles in allem gibt es von mir eine Kaufempfehlung und eine Bewertung mit 7/10 Sternen.


Für die, die Vanishing Realms schon durch gespielt haben und jetzt auf neuen Content warte, hier meine Spieletipp: Trickster VR (ähnlich zu Vanishing Realms aber mehr Fokus auf Kampf und Waffen).


Viel Spaß

22962855.review:
That is how RPG's should be played. There is no abstraction of the gameplay. No click this or that. No button smashing. Just do what you want. Grab the sword, block the attacks. Take the torch and reach to the candles on the wall to light them. Look under the table or bend over to look inside the chest and grab the coins and treasures.

Parrying and hitting with the sword is satisfying, although the incoming attacks of the enemies are very predictable after some time. The levels are very nice and i like the inventory system. 

In future i would like to have a more grown up theme/design for this kind of games and interesting dialogs. And of course it is too short as always.

22962076.review:
This game is absolutely amazing and epitomizes everything I had hoped VR could deliver. Other developers would do well to study this game very closely.

The interactions with the world are so well implemented that this provides the deepest sense of presence that I've felt in a VR game. I was giddy and had a ridiculous grin on my face the first time I found a pickaxe and started wailing on ore deposits. Just holding a torch is a simple joy and illustrates what a massive difference a simple little thing like holding a light source in your hand and moving it around to move things in and out of shadow can have on immersion.

The visuals are cartoony but still impressive and a pleasure to look at. I'd love to see a more realistic rendering of this world in VR, but I am by no means complaining. The world is lovely.

The combat is great too. The mix of ranged and melee combat gives you a nice variety. There's nothing quite like standing up against multiple opponents with your sword and shield in hand, trying to deflect and counter their rain of blows. Hiding behind cover and peeking your head out to shoot of an arrow is a lot of fun too.

22920508.review:
Just the other day I had a look at this game and thought, "Ugh, looks overpriced and pretty gimmicky - even for a VR game." I decided to take the plunge, as much for lack of other content as anything.

This has been the single best experience I've ever had in gaming - by a wide margin. Not just VR, everything.

Tips to super-enjoying this:

1. Let yourself be immersed. Try and BE the character you're playing. I felt giddy with excitement and anticipation by the end of this game because I let myself believe I was there.
2. Move around frequently in your play-space. Since you teleport a lot in this game you can lose a sense of immersion if you do it too often. So just make sure you shift around a lot. Be free.
3. If you do 1. right, then make sure you fight your enemies like they're going to bludgeon you to death if they actually land a hit. It'll put the hairs up on the back of your neck.

Legit criticisms:

1. AI is pretty crap in this. Enemies aren't smart and just sit there staring at you even though you're only 2 meters away.
2. AI fights incredibly slowly. This is probably just the designers deciding to ease people in - but more frantic fights would be amazing.
3. AI doesn't really adapt to your fight style - I'm sure this will be fixed in other games given time. But basically, enemies should be a bit more clever about blocking and dodging blows that you repeatedly land.
4. Textures could do with a bump in resolution, but honestly, it doesn't matter too much since you get lost in the moment.
5. MOAR CONTENT! Left me desperate for more.

Conclusion:

This is the single best entertainment experience I've ever had. This game is amazing. It's a cliche, but seriously: this game is a must-have.

If you don't have a Vive. Get a Vive. Get this game. No joke.

22913611.review:
This is the first ever review I have written for a game on Steam.  I was motivated to write it because, out of all the VR games I own, this has been the most fun and awe-inspiring experience on the HTC Vive to date.  It's basically a Zelda-like game where you are actually inside the dungeon.  I own many other VR games and in my opinion this is way better than Job Simulator and the Lab, which feel more like VR tech demos.  Vanishing Realms is a very short game.  I was able to complete the available content in a little less than 3 hours or so.  It does have a lot of interesting mechanics and once you get used to the movement and combat, it is one of those games that make you salivate about what the future of VR has in store.  I am not going to describe the game itself, as you can get that from the Store page.  I will describe the experience though.  

The initial chapter of the game sees your character locked inside a dungeon that you must try to escape by finding keys, following hints in riddles or defeating various types of enemies.  It is very immersive, and you really feel as if you are inside this world, to the point that I often found myself swinging my "sword" outside the playable area and bashing my furniture (make sure you have enough room to play as the game suggests a larger playing area than most other games).  Fighting multiple enemies is fun and sometimes challenging, as enemies will change their attack patterns after a bit and dodge your arrows and magic attacks.  The weapons right now are limited to three different swords and a hammer for melee, two different bows and a fire magic wand for ranged attacks.  Enemies vary based on their abilities and you will find yourself fighting skeleton warriors, archers, mages (as well as healers) and a few bigger baddies and bosses.  Once you complete the initial dungeon, you are teleported to an arena-style area where you have to defeat all the enemies within a time limit in order to complete the game.  The game has various checkpoints whereby you can save your progress by walking over them.

I own several other VR games such as Holopoint, VR Minilands Golf, Job Sim, the Lab, The Blue, etc (just check my game list).  Vanishing Realms doesn't have a high replayability index, but is a way better experience for the price than many other VR games available now.  The only downsides to this game are its brevity, the lack of guidance at certain points (although it's not that hard to figure out) and the semi-ambiguous ending, although it does seem like the developer is working on more content.  I have to say that at this point, this is the only VR game I own that I have been motivated to play all the way through.

Again, I definitely recommend this game to anyone who owns the Vive and wants to get a good idea of what VR can potentially offer in a gaming experience.  I really felt like I was inside this world and I would be completely immersed in the fights and the game mechanics.  Some things could still use a bit of polish but I definitely think this is an experiencee worth checking out if you are into VR.

22905996.review: It's rudimentary gameplay and simple storyline attest to the infancy of consumer virtual reality, but don't let that fool you.  Vanishing Realms is to SteamVR what Super Mario Brothers was to the NES - an outstanding introduction to a burgeoning new realm of possibilities.  This SHOULD BE the first game every new VR owner should play.

22891974.review:
After playing dungeon crawling games like Diablo and Zelda in your younger days, have you ever wave an invisible sword and shield around pretending that you are the hero bashing and killing monsters around you? I know I have. And Vanishing Realm made my dreams come true.

Made by an ex-Valve dev (yes, singular), Vanishing Realm puts players into, quite literally, the boots of a lone adventurer, armed only with his/her wits and thirst for adventure. The cartoony nature of the game may seem like a mood breaker for some, but trust me when I say all these will go away once you hold the sword in your hand for the first time, or when you that huge skeleton swung its flail right above your head as you franctically ducked instinctively.

The battle was fluid and engaging, requiring players to parry, dodge and attack with good timing and precision. However, once you get used to the mechanics, it can get a little too easy, even in boss fights. The variety of weapons is also quite limited at this time as the game is still in early access. 

However, the potential of this game is huge and it could very well revolutionise dungeon crawling adventure games as Ocarina of Time did at the time of its release. Definately recommend this game if you fancy this genre!

22889008.review:
The first enemy scared the hell out of me when he appeard and swung his weapon down on me. Admittedly, I made a not-sexy noise, but this visceral fear caused me to raise my sword to protect my head from the attack as if I was in real danger. There was no tutorial or guide on how to block attacks. No button to press. Just reflex.

After about an hour in this game my legs ached from walking/ducking/dodging, my arms were tired from fighting monsters, and my character’s health was low so I took a break by sitting on my bedroom floor under a beautiful tree. Leaves fell all around me. Birds were chirping. The wind was blowing. Particles swam in a sunbeam. I reached into my virtual satchel, pulled out an apple, brought it to my mouth, and slowly “ate” it as it replenished my health. Sitting there regaining my virtual and real-life stamina was the most peaceful, beautiful, and interconnected experience I have ever had with technology. Half-man, half-machine. Nirvana through escapism. By the way, I opened my mouth to eat the apple and hit my teeth with the controller. I've also tried to set my controllers on tables that don't exist multiple times.

If you are reading this review a couple of years after the Vive's release I am sure there will be better games to spend your money on. But as a launch title this is among the best available. I highly recommend it.

22873304.review:
This game is excellent. Very much reminiscent of Zelda on N64.  The teleport to move mechanic works flawlessly.  Atmosphere and gameplay are fun and enjoyable. I want to see a dozen more chapters!

One thing that bothered me was that unlike many other room-scale games Vanishing Realms has no feature which keeps your point of view primarily away from your computer monitor or television. During my entire playthrough of chapter 2 (since it follows more of a single direction of movement - unlike chapter 1's more roaming exploration) I was facing directly toward my monitor and there was nothing I could do about that. For that reason i'd classify this game as more dangerous to near-by displays than other titles. I had smacked my controllers into walls as well my monitor (which I had thankfully covered with a thick cardboard box for safety) during melee combat several times. I play in a 8ft by 10.5ft play area. Many of the other games I've played will utilize the location of the monitor/computer in the room and set the default facing direction as away from the monitor.

The game takes about 2 hours to finish. That said I wouldn't consider the game worth its current price with its currently limited amount of content. To justify the price I believe the final product (after early access ends) should have have at least two or three times as much gameplay as what we can currently enjoy in the first two chapters. I mean paying $10 per hour for first play-through content is a little rediculous. 

I also felt that some of the game's design elements were created to keep the early access beyond Steam's 2 hour refund period. For example time-consuming use of a mining-pick to obtain gold (which is neccessary to proceed), as well as the cryptic hints on how to proceed to the end of each chapter or how to pass through certain doorways.

22837414.review:
Although I haven't completed it yet, I really enjoyed this game. There hasn't been a single moment where I felt uncomfortable or disoriented in the time I have played.

The combat is a little slow paced but I suppose it is for the better after trying other games that had fast paced combat which can make you feel uncomfortable and outright dangerous if designed wrong especially when fights get so intense that you forget about your chaperone bounds.

The cable you are tethered to also hampers your movement so I can't move quickly comfortably because I am always worried about tripping over the wire or smacking into a wall despite the chaperone warning which is often neglected in really heated moments. So I find it good that this game took a slower paced approach.

But the combat was far from snail paced, It was quite entertaining dueling with archers and sword skeletons, trading steel and arrows, dodging and blocking, and taking cover.

The AI though not the smartest in the world somehow seemed to react to my actions, sword fighters sometimes try to pull a fient on you dodging your attacks and swiftly counterattacking for instance. If you try to cheese the game with a bow from a distance eventually your foes start to dodge them.

The foes seem to have a set distance at which they will engage you, the fights are a little slower paced which I don't mind since you have time to plan your next move and don't run out of space as easily.

I found the level design to be nice and clever but far from flawless, there were some places where I felt a disconnect. For instance trying to telport from a ledge to an archer that has been harassing me but it would only allow me to teleport to this one specific little spot on the ground without any visual cues so I was sitting there for ages figuring out how to get there.

I found the inventory system to be quite intuitive, though sometimes it sticks out like a sore thumb when interacting with objects beneath you.

The art style was beautiful despite the simple cartoony looking graphics. Looks pretty good in VR, I loved the god rays coming out of the windows early on in the game. The skyboxes can use some work though.

The puzzles I've encountered so far are nice, but very short and simple.

It is good that the developer added some measures against cheesing the game, like abusing your available space to access areas you should not be able to otherwise.

All in all, I would really recommend this game, it is worth a try even if you don't happen to like RPGs.

The use of the Vive is sweet! this is worth every penny although the graphics aren't superb but good enough.  If you create a good gameplay then graphics are not as important (As the Wii showed us). 22836127.review:
I'm having a hard time coming deciding what to say about this game. It's basically Zelda-light in VR. It has so many elements that are really good, but not perfect, though the combination of them in one game is great. 

Swordplay feels fantastic, parrying with a sword is just as fun as you could imagine, and blocking with a shield only to then stab the skeleton in between the armor and the shield like in 300 is crazy fun. 

The loot system where you actually destroy things and then grab the loot is great, the new inventory system (essentially a belt) works pretty well, and is decently unobtrusive. 

The other weapons that I won't spoil are OK, but could be better. The puzzles work pretty well, though the traps, while cool looking, didn't really seem to work for me with teleporting. 

Overall, this is a game with a lot of very cool elements. It makes me more excited for VR's potential than probably any other game I've played. As I said before, nothing is quite perfect... but everything is pretty good. The only real criticism is, of course, the length of the game. My play-time is inflated because 2 people have played it. It is somewhere shy of 2 hours long. It is an early access game, and the dev apparently is planning on adding another chapter. There is no doubt that this is a very cool game, and I don't regret getting it, but it would not be my first purchase.

22823772.review:
Das beste VR-Spiel zur Zeit.

Trotz Early-Access wirkt das Spiel fertiger als viele andere Spiele. Die Steuerung ist einfach nur genial, da können sich manch andere Spiele eine Scheibe von abschneiden.

Mit Schild und Schwert oder Bogen und Pfeil wird der Mann wieder ein Kind. Die Welt ist atmosphärisch animiert und die Physik funktioniert tadellos. 

Was dem Spiel noch fehlt ist Early-Access typisch noch eine vernünftige Storyline. Das Spiel hat das potenzial zum ersten VR-Blockbuster für die HTC-Vive.

22823440.review:
Vanishing Realms ist das erste 'echte' Roomscale-Spiel dass ich probiert habe.

Man bewegt sich im Dungeon bzw. in der zugehörigen Umgebung, und insbesondere die Innenräume vermitteln den Eindruck von Räumen in denen man sich befindet. Es erinnert an die alten Eye-of-the-Beholder, in denen man sich jetzt mittendrin befindet. Oder ein wenig ein 3d-mittendrin-Zelda.

Die Welt ist nicht riesig, und es geht relativ linear vorwärts . Aber das fällt während dem Spiel nicht weiter auf.
RPG-Teil gibt es quasi keinen, VR ist eher ein Dungeon-Crawler.

Auch wenn es etliche Punkte für 'hier geht noch was' gibt, ist VR eine runde Sache. Durch den Blick auf alte  PC-Titel liegt evtl. die Messlatte auch zu hoch für eine 'neutrale' Betrachtung. Alles in allem ist VR für Freunde von Dungeon-Spielen allemal einen Blick wert, wenn nicht sogar ein MUST-HAVE.

Soweit das 'ursprüngliche' Spiel, Chapter 1.

Das hinzugekommene Chapter 2 besteht leider nur aus einer grafisch netten, aber 'passiven' Burg und einem Kampfstrang, bestehend aus 9 zeitbegrenzten Einzelteilen.

Die Kämpfe und deren Mechanik sind super implementiert, und man geht ganz im Geschehen auf. Die präzise Mechanik im Nahkampf demonstriert eindrucksvoll den Gewinn an Spielqualität mit getrackten Controllern.

Ich hatte allerdings dabei das Problem, dass mein Spielbereich mit 2.5x2.5m zu klein für die Schwertkämpfe ist und ich regelmässig Wände und Einrichtung getroffen habe, trotz dauerhafter Bodenmarkierung und Rücken an der Grenze. Und mit Gegnern von hinten geht selbst das nicht.

Mein Tip: mit weniger als 3m Platz eignet man sich besser von vornherein einen Kampfstiel mit einem Bewegungsradius von Essbesteck an. In Eifer des Gefechts im Ausfallschritt mit gestrecktem Arm den Controller in eine Wand oder teures Mobiliar zu hämmern geht verdammt schnell. Die vielgerühmte Immersion mit Roomscale tut hier perfekt ihren Dienst.

Insgesamt ist das zweite Kapitel nett für einen Durchgang und , aber ich hätte lieber mehr von Art des ersten Kapitels gehabt.

Oh wow. This is by far my favourite VR game of the 10 I have tried so far. Really immersive, and lots of fun.

22749551.review:
Il est très difficile de noter un jeu de ce type, mon avis est mitigé, mais le résultat est sans appel : c'est la première fois que je demande à me faire rembourser un jeu sur Steam.
Alors oui l'univers est assez bien modélisé, c'eet sympa de vraiment taper avec une épée comme on le ferait en vrai, mais le jeu a pour moi deux défauts majeurs : 
- la téléportation
- l'absence de scénario

Pour la téléportation beaucoup diront que c'est le choix majoritairement retenu par les développeurs. Alors oui dans un Budget Cuts ou un The Lab ça fonctionne sans soucis c'est vrai. Mais Budget Cuts étant un jeu d'infiltration on ne peut pas abuser de ce déplacement et TheLab... ça n'est pas vraiment un jeu. Ici on se retrouve à ,pouvoir traverser toute la map en restant debout sans même faire un pas, en passant au milieu de tous les pièges en parcourant des kilomètres en quelques secondes !! Du grand n'importe quoi. AU minimum aurait-il fallu mettre en place un système de stamina pour éviter de pouvoir cliquer à gogo, pouvoir fuire les combats (les ennemis n'essaynt mlême pas de vous poursuivre) sans craintes. Ce style de jeu doit trouver une autres mécanique que celle-là.

Pour le scénario (alors bon je ne suis pas bilingue et des détails m'ont échapper à la lecture des parchemins en "intro") il est quasi inexistant :( pour un RPG c'est vraiment dommage quand même. Il y a un embryon de scénario mais rien de convainquant.

Alors oui, le jeu est hyper immersif, c'est jouissif (les premières minutes) de se balader dans cet univers en marchant, mais franchement c'est plus une démo technique qu'un vrai jeu et en plus je ne suis pas convaincu.

Le jeu a du potentiel mais doit fortement évoluer pour avoir un pouce en l'air.

22748311.review:
Wow. Have only played 20 minutes on this game, but this is what I was always looking for in VR. Think Zelda in style, going around collecting gems and loot with a flame torch in one hand and a sword in the other

The teleport system that is being used with VR seems solid... but with games like this, that looks so convincing in VR, I just want to walk and walk and walk. It would be cool to see some kind of game design that employs Unseen Diplomacy’s technique of room control. Anyway, that is more a criticism of how unbelievably convincing VR is, and how much of a shame it is when you see the Chaperone Boundaries come up.
If you are new to the Vive, buy this now. Best game I have played on it yet, and actually feels like a game rather than a tech demo.

EDIT:

Chapter 2 is dreadful... it really left a sour taste in my mouth to the entire experience. Gone is the wonderful RPG exploration with puzzles, in is a battle area with time limit. It feels like the poorest excuse of level padding and it really wasn't fun. When it gets to the end, I wasn't even sure it was the end and wasted lots of time trying to find out what I have to do next. I really want to see the dev change this, otherwise this review will turn to negative once the game leaves EA.

EDIT 2 (in Progress

The update has made the combat much much harder and much more fun. Unfortuatly you can beat the game by crouching (the AI can't cope with it). Vast improvement in smashable objects and little puzzles (such as throwing rocks to knock down goblets etc). This update puts me back in positive mind set about the Developer, although I am not looking forward to "chapter 2"... hopefully it has also been updated in a good direction.

If you have already played this game before the update, get stuck back in right now!

22717508.review:
OK...hands down, if you want the tl;dr-- "This is one of THE games to buy for the Vive. It is a must-play. It is not even finished and it is already completely amazing, worth the price it is charging and definitely a go-to demo for the true power of VR as a medium for storytelling and compelling gameplay. Get off the fence, come down here and buy this."

This is no tech demo and you can't even get a slight idea of what its like from the pictures and teaser video... this is meat on the bone single-player mystery/puzzle/action RPG. Its duration is short at the moment compared to AAA titles, but it is early access and still well worth the price. This game has the perfect all-around mix of mechanics, story, artistic flare and mystery to bring you fully into another world. The words to describe the experience would be things like, stupendous, rewarding, enthralling, memorable, thought-provoking. 

I've played games like this before...and from an abstracted point of view, everything in Vanishing Realms has been done before, but you've NEVER done what you do in Vanishing Realms. If you played Spell Fighter-- that was a taste, but this is the whole bite. It has the hallmarks of a good RPG game but this time YOU do it for real. Every sword swing is your own. You can cast magic and its not some autotargeting system..if you don't point your wand correctly your spell will fly off and sputter doing nothing. When you pull the bowstring on your bow and let it go...you better aim true. 

You'll find yourself crouching or sitting down after a battle, panting while you put virtual food to your face to gain health and mana. 
You'll be dueling mortal combat with larger-than-life monsters, trading blows, parrying and ducking around your playspace to dodge. 
You'll curse and swear and fight with all your strength as you realize monsters don't play fair, or wait in line to kill you.
You'll hide behind a virtual rock for cover as a wizard casts wicked magic your way.
You'll parry arrow shots inches from your body with expert timing using just your sword. 
You'll search every nook and cranny for secrets, hidden loot, questionable keys and forgotten treasures. 

You'll be completely blown away by this game.

22684994.review:
Vanishing Realms ist mein erstes Spiel, welches ich mir für die Vive dazu gekauft habe. Bei der allgemeinen Preisbalance wo die VR Spiele liegen, hab ich lange hin und her überlegt. Mein alltime Fav. Game ist Dark Souls. Also wollte ich etwas zum erkunden, sowie ein brauchbares Kampfsystem. Vanishing Realms bietet sowas im kleinen. Das Kampfsystem KANN ordentlich genutzt werden, aber auch ein rumgefuchtel wie bei Wii-Titel führt zum Erfolgt und erledigten Gegner. Ich rate für die Immersion trotzdem ordentlich zu spielen, was den Spielspaß erhöht. Das Erkunden ist beim erstmal richtig richtig klasse, flacht aber beim erneuten Spielen schneller ab. Da nichts random platziert wird. Aber das ist okay, würde man jedem anderen Single-Playertitel auch nicht ankreiden. Jedoch wirkt ein erneuter Durchlauf, weniger spannend. Daher sei dies angemerkt.
Der WoW-Look ist gut gewählt bei der momentanen Performance situation. Es verbreitet Stimmung, aber keine Panik beim erkunden der Gemäuer. Ein kleiner Jumpscare zum Anfang. Der aber wirklich nicht der rede wert ist ist auch dabei. Ich liebe Horrorfilme sowie Spiele, und das genannte Dark Souls hat natürlich auch viele solcher verstörenden Elemente. Jedoch wirkt in VR so etwas immer noch eine Ecke krasser und Intensiver. Daher bin ich froh, dass dieses Game nie zu dunkel oder zu furchteinflössend daher kommt. Es macht Spaß, sich eine Fackel zu greifen und hier und da ein bisschen Indiana Jones art die Gänge zu beleuchten, auch wenn dies nie notwendig ist. Da alles hell genug bleibt. Man macht es trotzdem und man fühlt sich wieder ein paar Jahre jünger und baut sich ein Spiel im Spiel damit. 

Ich habe zu diesem Zeitpunkt den ersten Akt in gut einer Stunde durchgespielt. Was auch wirklich mein persönliches Limit war. 
- Das Erkunden (soweit möglich von meinem Wohnzimmer), funktioniert mit RoomSkaling und blinking bzw. teleportieren zu neuen Abschnitten kombiniert wirklich gut. Auch rückwärts, um sich platz zu schaffen, wenn Gegner vor einem stehen. Macht man dies zuu schnell verspürt man gerade gegen Ende ein wenig Übelkeit. Aber alles im Rahmen und verglichen mit dem, was ich mit dem Dev-Kit1 der OR damals durchgemacht habe. Ein Kinderspiel. Man ertappt sich dabei, wie man hier und dort unter Möbeln schaut und jede Ecke untersuchen möchte. Ob nicht doch noch irgendwo etwas versteckt ist.
- Das Kämpfen funktioniert wie schon gesagt gut, kann aber auch in fuchtellei ausatmen. Gerade wenn man seine persönliche Pause machen will, bzw. einfach nur noch den Akt beenden will, weil man erschöpft ist. Die KI ist wirklich nicht der rede Wert, die Skelette fuchteln ein wenig, schreien dich an (perfekter Zeitpunkt um ins Auge zu stechen) und schwingen ihr Schwert aus 2 Richtungen. Ansonsten bleiben sie hinter ihren Schild und warten eher das man auf sie zu kommt. Was gut ist. Denn in VR wird vieles schnell hektisch: "Wo bin ich gerade im RL? Hoffentlich ist vor mir nicht der Fernsehr, kurz umschalten zur Kamera. Neu Positionieren. Kabel richten. Okay weiter gehts!" Solche Momente wird man hier alle 2 min erleben, gerade wenn man nur etwa 3x2 Meter platz hat. Ich habe fast meine Freundin aufm Sofa einmal getroffen. Gerade wenn man voll dabei ist. Oder nur ein paar Münzen sammeln will. Daher ist es gut, dass die Gegner eher passiv agieren und dem Spieler sehr viele Chancen bieten. Ich denke das ist ein guter Kompromiss, zwischen Spielspaß und Sicherheit.
- Die Technik dahinter. Ich mag mich täuschen, aber ich glaube vieles ist Asset, was im Unitystore angeboten wird. Aber das macht mir nichts. Man muss den WoWartigen Look aber mögen. Dafür bleibt die Performance auch meist Stabil. Bei zu vielen Lichtquellen hatte ich hier und da ein zucken gesehen. Was aber auch an meiner 770 GTX (4gb vram) liegen kann. Die Eingaben funktionieren tadellos und man merkt, dass sich viele Gedanken gemacht wurden. Einzig das man nicht runterfallen kann, wenn man sich auf Kisten portet finde ich etwas schade. Aber eine Kleinigkeit. Was mich mehr stört ist das Speichersystem, was eher Checkpointartig funktioniert. Ich hatte mal einen Soundausfall und wollte Steam neu starten und stand wieder vor New Game. Tut nicht not. 


Unterm Strich möchte ich Jedem Vanishing Realms empfehlen, der einmal als Ritter Dungeons erkunden möchte. Die Spielzeit mag (momentan) kurz wirken und der Wiederspielwert gen Null. Jedoch muss man sich vor Augen führen, dass VR nach einer Stunde schon anstrengend ist. Ich denke Sessions werden niemals 4-6 Stunden in Angriff nehmen. Zumindest wenn man so aktiv agiert wie hier. Und auch wenn man nach einem mal Spielen alles gesehen hat, denke ich schaut man vielleicht hin und wieder noch mal rein, um ein paar Monster zu metzeln. Der Preis geht in Ordnung. Ich bin gespannt ob und was noch alles nachgeliefert wird. Aber es fühlt sich jetzt schon wie ein richtiges Spiel an, was das wichtigste erfüllt. Es macht Spaß!

22681233.review:
I think this may be my first review (just saw I also reviewed Orion Prelude....ha).  There's so many things I want to say about this game.  For one, I have been waiting 12 years to play this game.  I know, it's only been a twinkle in a developer’s eye for a few months or so, but that doesn't change anything.

When I was playing Morrowind, I wanted it to be this game.  When I played Diablo 1, I wanted it to be this game.  Heck, when I read books...I wanted them to be this game.  This game is not Morrowind or Diablo.  It's not any of those things.  This game is clunky, sloppy, graphically challenged (no offense, I still love them) and downright fantastic. 

It has a taste, and truly just a taste, of everything I want in a video game.  Realistic sword movements, fun battles, gimmicky enemies, a touch of plot, a sprinkle of character, a hint of leveling, a smidge of puzzles, a dash of environmental interaction and a pinch of looting/customization.  This is by all means, a shadow of a good RPG.  But it doesn't matter.  We've all played these good RPGs, but what we want is to be in one.  This is as close as you can get right now.

My only negative is that it's tricky to interact with the belt, as in, a giant pain (unless I was doing something wrong) and it's too short.

Remember when you senselessly fought things with the Wii-mote?  Remember when you bought a Playstation move and for a few hours thought it was awesome until you realized that, meh, not that great?  Remember when you wanted to be playing this game?  Well, lucky for you, this is that game.

Buy it, support it, and get on the Dev's nerves about making it better and better.  I love this game.  

10/10 would snipe clipping skeleton king again.

22657495.review:
Early Access Watcher Reviews Vanishing Realms: Rite of Steel for HTC Vive

Update Version: Initial Release

Disclosure: The game copy was bought by the reviewer.

Before going into this review, it might be a good idea to hold a disclaimer over the rest of the talking points. I tested this game sitting down in a office desk chair and had to use my upper body to move. This game thankfully allows movement using the controller, teleporting you from one spot on the floor to another. You will need to have the HTC Vive in Room scaling mode to play this game and it was a bit of a challenge to play sitting down, but I will assure all the talking points will cover the universal approach and in no way will my reliability of a chair affect the opinion. That said, let us get to the main question. Is this RPG the grand attraction suited to introduce the functionality of the HTC Vive or is it another newcomer that might have gone on stage prematurely?

The dungeon and graveyard look astounding with a style similar to one of the latter Zelda games. Little cracks cover the walls and the wood bearings show off wear and tare. Skeletons are detailed beautifully with shields riddled with arrows and bruised dents in their armour. It really stood out the entire time I was playing it and I found myself more than once stopping to enjoy the atmosphere. It works very well to establish the mood, even if the actual inhabitants look more cartoonish than frightening. The music was a side note, painfully masked by the louder ambient noises of box hits, enemy strikes and arrow flings. I tried finding a way to change the volume, but I might have missed it. 

The tutorial is a welcome feature and covers the basics such as moving and picking up items. The rest of the features are rather self explanatory except for maybe the wand usage which as of now can be annoying when you attempt to put it away only to blast yourself with it. Items range from health potions, torches, a pick axe, food and puzzle items. Gold, jewels, mana stones, ore (from mining) and chalices add to the currency system used to buy weapons and potions. There are also ruby chalices hidden throughout the dungeon to collect for an achievement, but it also provides gold and mana. It is simple enough to pick up items and the only issues with it are being close enough to reach, but with the teleport movement style I have not had an issue reaching anything. UI consists of slots that appear around your waist and include categories for weapons, potions, wand, bow and items. The item slot is a bit annoying when trying to grab certain items (have to go through each item until you get the one you need) and you cannot drop items. There is a limit to how many items you can carry so unless you stockpiled on fruits before grabbing the pick axe, you should be fine.

Combat is a typical hack and slash standoff against skeletons and ghosts. As long as the enemy can see you and are in range, they will attempt to hit you as a group (space must be available to accommodate multiple melee so bottlenecking into a short gap is usually recommended). Weapons and a shield are either bought or found and weapons range from swords, bows (use off hand to pull back arrow), hammer or a wand (uses mana and you point, hold trigger and release). Dual wielding is possible as well as parrying to deal with melee hits, but the shield is crucial against arrows and moving is the only way to avoid fireballs. It is very simplistic in nature with the majority just being massive flailing of the controller, but it is recommended to time attacks and use movement to gain a upper hand. It can get very tiring during the fights later on. Death is not to harsh on the player at least. 

The look and feel of the game cannot overcome the barren amount of content though. Going through the first level can take about 30-45 minutes if you are going slow and the arena style matches can keep that stretched to about an hour and fifteen. There is a total of 11 ruby chalices to collect and 33 ore spots to harvest for achievements, but all of this can be done in one pass if you look half-effort. It can be hard for some to make it the whole way in one play through with the forty plus monsters you so thankfully their is checkpoint saving, but if someone wants to play, they either start where you left off or erase the entire save and start from the beginning. Outside of this, there were some random moments I experienced missing frames and was kicked out of the game to the Vive menu (it started were I left off when I entered the app again). 

During my second play through, the game starting feeling like an endurance test over anything else. The simple wonder of discovering what was behind the next corner really helped keep the magic alive during the first play through. I still enjoyed the scenery, but when I already knew what to expect it just felt boring. With only about an hour of gameplay and little replay value, it is hard to recommend when other products have so much more meat on their bones. I am eager to see what happens next, but for now it would be better to wait until a few more chapters at least justify the entry price.

Pros

- Beautiful aesthetic
- Fluid controls and combat feedback

Cons

- Very little content 
- Frame issues
- Couple of UI issues (item sorting/selection, miss fires with wand)

22655921.review: This game is totally awesome.  I always dreamed of exploring a dungeon and fighting mythical monsters, and this game delivers.  I truely hope this game sets the bar for other famtasy and Sci-fi RPG's - it's just a ton of fun to play.

22655908.review:
This is an incredible first attempt at an action RPG on the VIVE.  The visuals are gorgeous once you're inside of the game, and the use of roomscale is excellent if you have the room to move from different pieces of cover.  I had so much fun during the archer battles and ranged combat. 

The melee combat is a little less satisfying but still overall a great deal of fun.  Like others have said sometimes the enemies end up getting to close to you and it makes combat slightly awkward, granted once you learn how to teleport around the battlefield like a boss this becomes much less of an issue.  My only gripe with the melee combat.....why isn't there vibration on the wand when your sword makes contact with something?  That seems like it should be natural, and it would go a long ways towards immersion. 

The game is a bit on the short side, but it will make for an excellent demo game, and has proven to me that sword fighting can absolutely work (at least in single player) games with the Vive.  I was always confident that I could parry or block an attack that was coming without worrying about clipping, or feeling like my sword simply floats through the enemies.  

8/10 for now.  With more chapters and sword vibrations this could easily become a 9 or even 10/10.  

(seriously drinking potions? So badass.)

22627084.review:
Leute, was für eine Erfahrung ... Ich war ja schon immer ein RPG Fan, aber welche Art von RPGs möglich sind in VR hat mich echt weggeblasen. 
Die ganzen VR Komponenten finde ich hier einfach super durchdacht: Ich habe einen virtuellen Gürtel um die Taille, der alle Waffen, Tränke, Zauber und sonstigen Gegenstände aufbewahrt, daher kann ich auch ein relativ komplexes Inventar recht schnell verwalten - Das Winzige, was ich mir wünschen würde, wäre eine Art Oberfläche, in der ich meinen gesamten Gürtelinhalt verwalten könnte - wobei ich auch sehe, dass das Immersion kosten könnte. Auch verhält sich der Gürtel manchmal etwas komisch, irgendwie scheint er manchmal die Taille entlang zu rutschen, aber das könnte auch daran liegen, dass ich meine 2 Sensorboxen noch nicht fest verankert und ausgerichtet habe.

Das Laufen über die Teleportierfunktion ist auch sehr gut gelößt: Ich kann mich nicht einfach auf den nächsten Berg oder an einem Gegner vorbei teleportieren - leider kann ich aber einem Gegner entfliehen damit, da die Teleportation einfach viel schneller als jeder Gegner ist. Auch habe ich einen begrenzten Teleportastionsradius, der so ein bisschen die übliche "Schrittlänge" wiederspiegelt - man denke hier an Old-School Dungeonm Crawler wie Legend of Grimrock. Eine recht immersive Lösung, die Motion Sickness entgegenkommt. Wobei ich persönlich lieber eine Motion-Sickness gefährliche Lösung wie das "dashen" hätte, da ich in dem Punkt sehr unempfindlich bin und das meine Immersion steigern würde, aber nun gut - man kann auch nicht Alles haben und man will das Spiel ja auch verkaufen.

Und natürlich ist der Kampf einfach toll. Ob mit 2 Schwertern, mit Schild und Schwert oder mit Bogen: Das - wie sich jeder vorstellen kann - ist schlichtweg genial.

Alles in Allem ein absolutes Must-Have für Vive Besitzer. Schade zwar, dass es ein recht kurzes Vergnügen ist und im Early Access nur die Technik verbesser wird und nicht weitere Inhalte dazu kommen, aber es zeigt, wohin die Reise gehen kann.

22581644.review:
This might be my favorite VR game so far. It's a straightforward homage to classic dungeon-crawlers, except that you actually get to feel what it's like to crawl said dungeon. The enemies are intimidating, combat is satisfying, and the environments are great.

There are a lot of rough edges, to be fair. The bow is somehow simultaneously unsatisfying and OP. The inventory could use some work. Enemies don't have a ton of variety and the big bosses are "bullet sponges". But I don't care. I got to fight a skeleton in a dungeon with a sword.

22575267.review: Qu'elle expérience, qu'elle immersion! C’est ce qu’on appelle  la présence et difficile de se passer de VR après ça.  Bonne nouvelle les contrôleurs Vive sont plus solides que les murs qui s'en souviennent encore. A noter qu'étant sensible à la cinétose, 2 heures de jeux de suite et aucun mal de tête. Il y a quand même du potentiel d'amélioration niveau gameplay mais c'est le premier jeu VR qui m'a fait ressentir une telle immersion avec des combats épée, hache, arc, magie justes énormes. A conseiller donc, en attendant avec impatience les prochains chapitres.

22574953.review:
I am a long time Zelda fan (still have both games on my N64). That being said, this game is amazing. If you ever wanted to feel like you have been thrown into a Zelda game(literally), this is the game for you. Yes it is in early access and yes there are some minor issues like inventory management. But the came had way too many pros for such minor details to stop me. I played all of the Early Access content in one sitting, probably not a good idea, but I was addicted. It was one of the most immersive games in VR I have played so far. I didn't want to leave! Anyways here are some of the Pros and Cons I experienced, it may not be the same for everybody.

Pros++++++
-Immersive gameplay
- You get to hack and slash your enemies( or disintegrate them with fire!)
- Different weapons to suit your gamestyle(Archer, Knight, and Mage all mixed into one person)
- Fun exploration and beautiful artwork/surroundings
- A little bit of puzzle solving but nothing difficult
- You feel like you are actually wielding whatever weapon you choose!
- Some fun trap elements
- Addicting( I don't know if this is a pro or con)
- Some fun mini-boss and boss battles

Cons- - - - - (take lightly, it is still early access)
- Inventory system can be annoying. I wanted to navigate back to my torch but since I picked up practically everything I saw I had to spam my inventory until the correct item appeared.
- You need an ample amount of space of at least 2m x 2m.( not a problem for me, but could be for those with small areas)
- Not much else when it comes to cons.

Personal recommendation:  I wish some of the puzzles were a little more difficult to really add a challenge! (Again, still early access)

Well all things aside I do recommend this game for those that love the dungeon crawling and puzzle solving games. Or in other words, if you liked Zelda, you will like this game. It is only a few hours of content, but this is a game I want to support. I cannot wait for the full release of this game!

22572511.review: This is an amazing title that, if anything highlights how well an RPG can run in an environment like VR. However, I'll say that the game does have a shortcoming in that it also highlights the VR locomotion issue. Moving around via teleporting can be.. annoying. Especially if you don't have a lot of room. That's not to say it's the fault of the developer but this game more than most really shows that someone needs to work out a novel way to move around in VR.

Aqui os traigo lo que yo llamo el ANALISIS D.I.T.

DIVERSION:

El juego es increhiblemente divertido, realmente te sientes como un heroe, especialmente cuando te cargas al primer esqueleto usando la espada.

INMERSION: 

La inmersion es total. Realmente he recorrido esas mazmorras, y me he sentido parte de esa fantasia.  Al principio pensaba que el teletransporte iba a sacarme de la inmersion, pero en cuanto empiezas a preocuparte por que bicho te va a salir, se te olvida por completo los controles.
De hecho cuando estaba ahi dentro, yo en mi mano tenia una espada y un escudo, no tenia los controles.

TENSION: 

Digamos que tiene una tension media alta al principio del juego, en el que no sabes que monstruo te va a salir ni cuando.  Despues esa tension baja, y en realidad estas deseando que halla mas monstruos para luchar contra ellos. En cualquier caso, luchar contra un esqueleto guerrero cansa.

RECOMENDACION: SI, SI SI...  Jugarlo en cuanto podais. Yo me he sentido como un verdadero heroe exporando unas mazmorras. El coger la esapda en tu mano, y el sentir que puedes derrotar a estos monstruos con ella, es brutal y cuando tienes el arco en las manos te siente legolas total.

22555377.review: This game is somewhat short and the monster AI was a little weak, but overall I really enjoyed the experience.  The world is beautiful and is a pleasure to travel through.  The teleport system was extremely comfortable. I appreciated the consistency with direction, so teleporting while facing north will place you in the new location still facing north.  Some other VR games with Teleport will actually change your hero's orientation when you teleport which is, as you can imagine, very disorienting.  In this game I was never lost, I felt like I could keep track of where I was, where I had been, etc so it was a very enjoyable adventure through a nice fantasy world.

22528158.review:
One of the best experiences for the Vive available right now, but some of the squandered potential makes you craving more. 

The combat system is a bit clunky. I wish there was a greater feeling of weight to swinging the sword. Obviously design choices were made, but I'd rather not see virtual objects ever 'go through' other virtual objects even if it means disassociating the held object with your actual hand. In Job Simulator for instance, if you hold a mug and put your hand through a table the mug is stopped by the table and your hand continues through. Not only should your sword be physically blocked by an enemy shield but there should be a momentum calculation as well. One of the primary differences of the Vive from the Wii is that the controllers are tracked 1:1, real momentum calculations are possible; otherwise the combat will just feel gimmicky.

Another criticism would be the dreadful inventory system which the developer has already said he is going address. 

The environments look great and feel great in VR. There is so much here you won't find in any other VR game currently available. The developer has nailed a few core elements that make it fun and satisfying. 

It's worth picking up.

22523186.review:
I have played up to part 4 so far. This game is a dream come true for many reasons. It is not perfect, but it hits a lot of important parts.

Good:
- Nice visuals
- Intense combat
- The feeling of exploration is wonderful
- Simple RPG elements

Bad:
- The skeletons get to close during combat making it awkard to see
- Enemies ignore you till a certain distance (Not really bad in some cases)
- Short playtime (I haven't finished but know it is on the shorter side)

The game overall is very good. The enemies getting in your face so close you're almost looking through them is the biggest gripe. Otherwise it feels epic and looks great. Definitely a good first attempt at a fantasy RPG in VR. Can't wait to see more from this dev. I highly recommend this game. It maybe be short but it is a lasting impact.

22521404.review:
Short review: AMAZING!
Long review:
Played around two hours and I think I had a bug which meant I couldn't progress and had to restart once. For a game which is Early Access that's pretty good in my book.

The combat is really fun. 
- The Bow + Arrow combo is well balanced but could be much better if Van. R. adapts the system from Valve's The Lab instead of the one they are using. 
- Hammer and Sword are cool but they could feel a bit more "round". Maybe add a bit of vibrations when hitting the enemy or something like that.
- Shield is S-class, arrows pierce through a bit and give a super cool feeling. Not sure if there's vibrations actually. Was too immersed to really check that. It's just god damn statisfying learning the quirks and hits of every big dude and blocking the shit out of his strikes.
- Wand is OGMWTFBBQ.

General movement is pretty well done, although the auto pause is a bit too agressive when pointing your sword through objects but that's not so bad and can be turned off.

Some minor quirks with how far monsters "back off" when playing on a 2.5x2.5m roomscale but that's still not a big deal, short teleport and that is an interesting dynamic this way.

22516363.review:
I'm reviewing this as an early access game.  So yes I want it to be longer, and the inventory system needs work.  (I couldn't figure out how to drop something unless I put it in my inventory, so every time I would want my pick axe or torch I had to keep going through cheese and a bunch of apples I picked up to look at)  
However, the core of this game is really fun and I really like the art style, world design, and lore that has started to be developed.  I was sad when I finished this because I wanted more. 

If people are complaining that they can just teleport almost inside, and the waggle the sword around then I feel like that is one them for now.  Hopefully the enemies will be pushed back in the future.  For now, you can just teleport in front of them and then trade blows, blocks, and dodges the way it was intended to be played.  At one point near the end when it gets kind of hectic, I accidentally grabbed my old sword instead of my shield.  I didn't have enough time to switch back so I was duel wielding swords for awhile, and that was a lot of fun trying to move around and strike twice every time I saw an opening.

The auto pause was a little annoying at first.  Now, after playing some other VR games, I really like it.  It would be very hard to be in the middle of a fight and have to worry being up against the edge of your play space.  I am looking forward to seeing where this game goes in the future.

22494931.review: Vanishing Realms is among one of the most immersive VR games I have played to date. If you've ever wanted to be the hero in a tale able to strike down enemies with your sword, dodge and block incoming attacks, or even return fire with your bow; then buy this right now. There's about 2 hours of incredibly fun and immersive content, all while in early access. Totally worth it, especially since this game will be expanded even more in the future. If you want a something different than the endless VR shooters (not to be taking negatively, they are great for different purposes), Vanishing Realms offers a unique and immersive RPG experience not available anywhere else at the moment.

22491174.review:
This game shows off the potential for first person action RPGs with the HTC Vive. It's amazing for being the product of a single developer. I had a lot of fun with it, and I'm stoked for the rest of the game.

Not everything is perfect here. The inventory system felt clunky and I hated not being able to drop items.  You might have to click through all your misc items 20 times to find that torch you stashed after you've put 19 pieces of food there. Getting stuck inside an enemy is odd and the weight of the Vive makes constantly looking down at your bags a literal pain in the neck.

However, the complaints are insignificant when compared to the amount of fun this title delivers. A must for any Vive owner and part of my Top 5.

22462774.review:
If you want to try what Skyrim or first-person Diablo is like in VR, this is the game you want to buy. It's an action RPG with gear, loot and a few puzzle elements, but where it truly shines is in the combat.
